Experience: Gained a lot of very practical excel skills but do be warned the project requires you to find your own client and data which can not only be very challenging but the client may not expect the appropriate problem solving that your prof wants you to do. Best if you have connections with someone willing to provide data without high expectation for results and capable teammates, or it will be very tough if your teammates cannot manage the workload and dump the rest of the project on you. Expect to have frequent communication with your client and needing to revise your model several times too as real life models are not as simple as what is taught in class.
Improvement: find good teammates and have a project/client willing to cooperate early
CourseDescription: In this course, students acquire practical skills (bridging technology and real-world situations) in modeling and resolving business problems using personal computers. With computers becoming essential tools for executives in most organisations, knowing how to effectively use them to solve problems will be very helpful in other business courses and the student's future professional career.ObjectivesUpon completing the course, students will• Know how to frame problems, and integrate various analytical skills (e.g. statistics and mathematics) to model and address management concerns.• Be comfortable with the personal computer, motivated to self-learn problem analysis computer tools and know where to get relevant information and system resources.• Be familiar with a variety of software solutions (e.g. add-ins) and gain competency in using a spreadsheet application as an analysis, model verification, simulation and management reporting tool.

Experience: To be honest, this mod may be very useful for your future work if your job demands a lot of Excel skills. However, it is definitely challenging if you are a not a math person and/or have no experience with Excel before. I took SMA under prof Wang Hai in AY2021-2022 sem 2. His classes are expensive but trust me, they are worth the money! Prof is very very nice and considerate, and his lessons are very easy to follow. Based on my experience, there are two extra things that would probably help: 1. If possible, find your groupmates before bidding into the class. The project is heavy and intellectually challenging (if you want to score well), so good groupmates would really make your life a lot easier.  2. Final is tough, so be prepared for it…
Improvement: NIL
CourseDescription: In this course, students acquire practical skills (bridging technology and real-world situations) in modeling and resolving business problems using personal computers. With computers becoming essential tools for executives in most organisations, knowing how to effectively use them to solve problems will be very helpful in other business courses and the student's future professional career.ObjectivesUpon completing the course, students will• Know how to frame problems, and integrate various analytical skills (e.g. statistics and mathematics) to model and address management concerns.• Be comfortable with the personal computer, motivated to self-learn problem analysis computer tools and know where to get relevant information and system resources.• Be familiar with a variety of software solutions (e.g. add-ins) and gain competency in using a spreadsheet application as an analysis, model verification, simulation and management reporting tool.

Experience: SMA is one of the most useless courses for the working world, especially for skillsets that you "think" will be helpful in the working world.  Never in your life will you ever likely need to simulate a gas station queue or someone's monte carlo example unless you're a working in operations, or an absolute nutjob with nothing better to do in life. Took this mod because I thought I might learn something useful for internship/employers - what's important are basic stuff like index-match, xlookup, pivot tables and visualisation/handling of big data. As a Year 4 student, this has got to be one of the most useless mods I've ever taken to far. Thanks to SMA i can now model an approximate reduced bastardisation of a gas station queue! thanks profs! Took plenty of useless mods so far, this wins the top grand president's distinguished prize of the highest honor  Out of all the working professional friends I've talked to, absolutely NOBODY has ever told me they've used excel solver in the work, and it's unintuitive AND slow. Exceptional example of academic bloat and mismatch between curricula/real world.
Improvement: Out of everything you learn, approximately 5~10% of it will actually be useful in the working world, depending on your job. Save your grades and soul and avoid this especially if it's not compulsory. You can learn excel on the job or via courses online without screwing your GPA further than it already is. People tell you oh its useful for internship UH YEAH OK you can just ask your friends to teach you the most useful functions, or borrow their notes. Save your misery and trouble.  edit: lmao look at the reviews with most number of negatives, SMA is an ancient piece of outdated jokie, they literally give you videos of a prof teaching excel from 2013 and before bro
CourseDescription: In this course, students acquire practical skills (bridging technology and real-world situations) in modeling and resolving business problems using personal computers. With computers becoming essential tools for executives in most organisations, knowing how to effectively use them to solve problems will be very helpful in other business courses and the student's future professional career.ObjectivesUpon completing the course, students will• Know how to frame problems, and integrate various analytical skills (e.g. statistics and mathematics) to model and address management concerns.• Be comfortable with the personal computer, motivated to self-learn problem analysis computer tools and know where to get relevant information and system resources.• Be familiar with a variety of software solutions (e.g. add-ins) and gain competency in using a spreadsheet application as an analysis, model verification, simulation and management reporting tool.

Experience: Disclaimer: I took this module under Prof Manoj Thulasidas.  This module does a great job of exposing me to various, lesser used Microsoft Excel features. It also provides me with greater confidence in utilising Microsoft Excel. By paying close attention to the seminars, one should find the individual assignments somewhat manageable. By practising, one should be able to tackle the final examination and get a somewhat satisfactory score (but finishing the whole paper and/or getting full marks, will require more effort).
Improvement: I do feel that more assistance should be provided with regards to the group project. Asking students to source for their own clients and to scope out their projects with reference to content that they have not been taught (as this stage of the project is done around week 4) are two very challenging tasks. It also should be noted that many of the concepts in SMA are taught at a rather basic level. Thus, for further proficiency (though not needed for SMA's assessments), one may need to continue studying and exploring beyond SMA. For example, to better comprehend the Solver feature, one may choose to take the Decision Analysis module.

Experience: Content wise, it is rather okay with only 7 weeks of actual learning materials and the rest can be focused on the project. Project wise, have to work with external company for the data, which can make it hard as you need to source for one if your group have no contact or find for open source data. Very practical if you need to use excel in the future.
Improvement: Update content, as some of the exercises were not updated for a while.
CourseDescription: In this course, students acquire practical skills (bridging technology and real-world situations) in modeling and resolving business problems using personal computers. With computers becoming essential tools for executives in most organisations, knowing how to effectively use them to solve problems will be very helpful in other business courses and the student's future professional career.ObjectivesUpon completing the course, students will• Know how to frame problems, and integrate various analytical skills (e.g. statistics and mathematics) to model and address management concerns.• Be comfortable with the personal computer, motivated to self-learn problem analysis computer tools and know where to get relevant information and system resources.• Be familiar with a variety of software solutions (e.g. add-ins) and gain competency in using a spreadsheet application as an analysis, model verification, simulation and management reporting tool.

Experience: I highly recommend this mod to everyone as Excel is a very useful tool and this mod really teaches you a lot about it and most importantly gives you many opportunities to apply and practice your skills. At first I was put off by the demanding group project (have to work with real world client and source for it yourself) but in the end it wasn't that bad and was in fact a great way to apply all that we had learnt to make something with practical value. The profs also provide an insane amount of resources- lecture videos, class exercises, lots and lots of practice questions- it's almost overwhelming (but you don't HAVE to do it all, hence the manageable workload). I really learnt a lot from this mod while having fun, 10/10 would do it again if I could!
Improvement: Include SPILL/array functions and Pivot Tables in the syllabus
CourseDescription: In this course, students acquire practical skills (bridging technology and real-world situations) in modeling and resolving business problems using personal computers. With computers becoming essential tools for executives in most organisations, knowing how to effectively use them to solve problems will be very helpful in other business courses and the student's future professional career.ObjectivesUpon completing the course, students will• Know how to frame problems, and integrate various analytical skills (e.g. statistics and mathematics) to model and address management concerns.• Be comfortable with the personal computer, motivated to self-learn problem analysis computer tools and know where to get relevant information and system resources.• Be familiar with a variety of software solutions (e.g. add-ins) and gain competency in using a spreadsheet application as an analysis, model verification, simulation and management reporting tool.

Experience: As of AY21/22  1. Horrible mod to take if you think this is a intro to Excel mod. You'll do good aside from the project...which seems to be the main stumbling block for most. The course throws you straight without introducing much Excel...do not take it if you are a absolute beginner who can't be bothered to learn on Youtube/Coursera/other MOOCs.    2. Project is killer. Work and bid with people or seniors (preferably) who have a better grasp on Excel or are pure geniuses. The project requirements are 'flexible' but you have to solve the client's problem, which could be unrealistic.   3. Course doesn't seem very effective in terms of teaching ... I find myself requiring to spend a lot of my time to go through the practices again after it is taught.  -yaos
Improvement: Project is way too hard. Client that you are working with may not provide you with the best data.  More likely, than not the outcome of your project looks good on the outside, but with severely flawed methodologies. i.e. you won't do well. More leniency should be looked at for projects that did not have much to work with, but for fairness, not realistically possible.

Experience: An interesting and useful module that teaches you slightly more than basic Excel. If you're completely new to Excel (like I was), it's recommended for you to self study the basic functions first because the pace of classes are very fast and if you're a relatively slower learner, you need to put in the extra hours to catch up with class content.

Experience: Taken AY20-21 Sem 2. Not an IS student and bidded alone. Scored A+ with consistent practice. It really isn't as scary as people say it is and I highly recommend it to everyone.  SMA is not an Excel 101 course. Not a math or programming course either (some knowledge of statistics and logic is helpful though). You will learn data analysis/visualisation/simulation techniques that show just how powerful and useful Excel is in optimising your workflow.  Simplicity is key for the project, you might be tempted to find a ton of real data but it's how you use it that counts. Final is challenging because of the limited time, but most people don't finish or pass the paper anyway so bell curve is not upset. Textbook not necessary.
Improvement: The content is recycled every year (since 2008-9). It may actually be a good thing, since you can easily get past year practices from seniors.

Experience: Basic knowledge of data structures & algos, EXTREMELY useful knowledge if you are going into anything tech. But as other reviews say, if you want to do well, be prepared to put in an insane amount of effort 'cause the workload and assessments are rough. I would spend weekends preparing for the following week's lecture.  Will admit that non-IS students have a disadvantage, so if you have a choice, don't take for the sake of taking. The teaching team is pretty bad, they just makes you watch pre-recorded videos that are 5 years old and don't really entertain questions.
Improvement: Know how to code. Or find a groupmate that knows how to code. Basic understanding of math (combinatorics, logarithms, summation) is good.
CourseDescription: Computational Thinking equips students to tackle complex computational problems; it trains students to design solutions to solve those problems using a computer program.  It draws upon concepts from mathematics and computer science – more precisely, discrete mathematics, data structures and algorithm design. This course will hone students’ analytical skills as they are challenged to think abstractly and computationally. Their minds will be open to the wonders of computing, as they go behind the scene to unravel the fundamental analytics that empower Google, consulting agencies and service companies. NOTE: To facilitate learning in this course, you are required to know and use programming.  You are advised to pick up the Python programming language before the course, for instance by practising with online tutorials such as http://learnpython.org.By taking this course, students will:• discover the science of computing • model problems and learn practical problem-solving techniques to tackle complex computational problems (beyond what a spreadsheet is capable of solving)• apply problem-solving techniques to develop more elegant and efficient programs• learn to write programs to represent and manipulate with complex data objects• understand the challenge of scale, not only in dealing with large data sets, but also in appreciating the nature of computing and computability

Experience: - Pre-assigned under Prof Cheng Shih-Fen.  - (Experience) Love-hate relationship with CIS-1702 but thoroughly enjoyed this mod. Very fulfilling when I think about the solution to tutorial, project problems but very frustrating and *normal* when I stumble on a question for very long (few hours, even days for me). Amongst all year 1 IS mods, this mod is the most enjoyable for me though it is also the most intellectually challenging.  - (Workload) Extremely high workload for me as a Y1S2 IS student, spent at least 32 hours per week (4 days) to prepare for next week's lesson and do the tutorial questions. The learning approach is blended learning where we are expected to (1) learn from the pre-recorded lectures on Youtube (Prof Hady's lectures), (2) attempt the self-check quizzes on eLearn and (3) do the tutorial questions before each class so that we clarify our doubts for the topic during class time. I used 1-2 days (morning to evening) to go through and take notes for next week's lecture, 2-3 days (morning to evening) to do the tutorial questions and review the code files provided. Most time consuming for me (cater at least 2 days to do one tutorial) as questions are challenging but doable.  - (Project) Struggled with project as some questions are very challenging and we may need to learn other algorithms on my own to solve the project questions. It is important to have solid understanding of each topic week by week to apply to the project. I had some question mark on certain questions from previous weeks and struggled to clear these questions before starting on the project. Start the project once it is released. Ask for help from instructors if necessary.  - Coding assistance were provided by the teaching team tp make use of to ask questions as well (I regret not using it for the project).  Advice to do well and enjoy this mod - Good math foundation (permutations, combinations, circular permutation, logarithm properties, arithmetic series, geometric series) for deriving big O notation. - Good python foundation (good to know how to implement a class) for understanding the code files provided and implementing algorithms for tutorial, project and exam questions. - Prepare ahead for each lesson (Prof Hady's youtube lectures are very well-explained so cater time to go through the videos) - "If I can't code it, I don't understand it" is a good motto. One strong recommendation to get a solid understanding of the concepts are (1) write my own class implementation for each data structure (Stack, Queue, Priority Queue, Binary Tree, Binary Search Tree, Graph, ...) and (2) re-code the algorithms taught. When in doubt, then refer to the code files provided to get a glimpse of what the code is doing, then get back to coding the class and algorithms on my own. After coding it out, compare with the code files provided and compare my code with the code files' codes for improvements. These greatly strengthened my understanding of the concepts taught.
Improvement: - Good if there are videos from the teaching team going through the thought process when coding the functions, class implementation for the code files provided.

There should be more avenues for help especially for project/lab as it can be a killer. This mod seem to favour people who are already good with coding
Improvement: Workload, quality of teaching

Improvement: I think python should be made a prerequisite for this module? As a core module doing that might have alot of negative backlash but students who go in without coding background really suffer for the projects imo.
CourseDescription: Computational Thinking equips students to tackle complex computational problems; it trains students to design solutions to solve those problems using a computer program.  It draws upon concepts from mathematics and computer science – more precisely, discrete mathematics, data structures and algorithm design. This course will hone students’ analytical skills as they are challenged to think abstractly and computationally. Their minds will be open to the wonders of computing, as they go behind the scene to unravel the fundamental analytics that empower Google, consulting agencies and service companies. NOTE: To facilitate learning in this course, you are required to know and use programming.  You are advised to pick up the Python programming language before the course, for instance by practising with online tutorials such as http://learnpython.org.By taking this course, students will:• discover the science of computing • model problems and learn practical problem-solving techniques to tackle complex computational problems (beyond what a spreadsheet is capable of solving)• apply problem-solving techniques to develop more elegant and efficient programs• learn to write programs to represent and manipulate with complex data objects• understand the challenge of scale, not only in dealing with large data sets, but also in appreciating the nature of computing and computability

Experience: I learned a lot about the basics of algorithms and how to apply them on Python. I also learned about fundamental data structures such as tree and graph. Last but not least, the mod really helped me in improving my coding and problem solving skills.
Improvement: I feel that the profoessor should also include basic materials such as Class for data structures as I find it quite difficult to interpret some of the problems sometimes.

Experience: It was very tough for me. A lot of the concepts seems to be A-Math to me. This is something I did not pick up in sec sch/poly. So personally, I found It very challenging. I took this mod when it was online so it was even worse. My only advice is to bid this mod with someone good in math or IS in general. OR make friends so that you can learn together.  The grading for me was confusing because I didn't know how I ended up passing even though i did not do well for all the test. So may the bellcurve be in ur favour.
Improvement: They have online videos to go through the answers etc but the videos are very touch and go in the sense where you should already understand the concepts. So if you don't understand the concepts, make sure you really solidify your understanding there.

Improvement: A lot of content was theoretical but to see it put into real applications was a lot harder, so more examples and class exercises could have been good instead.

Experience: My favourite mod in SMU so far i wish i could take it again because i love it so much. took this in AY2020-2021 sem2, it was very interesting and fun! i was very excited and happy to attend lesson every week.  People either hate or love this mod. understanding the new abstract-in-nature concepts well is the key that will make or break your CT experience.  Having background/experience(IS111, my only prior experience, was more than enough ) in python would be helpful because the projects and even open ended questions in midterms/finals, if you have more knowledge/hacks in python , you can come up with more ways quickly to solve a question and find the most efficient one from there. being ok at coding is also important so that you can carry yourself and the team especially if your group project partner cannot really contribute effectively for whatever reason. workload was generally manageable, just need to be consistent and do the weekly stuff etc.
Improvement: nil

Experience: (Note: took this module during AY20-21 Semester 2) Through this module, I learnt different approach towards questions posted. Yet my professor, I would say, is dry and lengthy. His lecture is somehow useful, yet not well-summarised enough and slides provided are not self-explanatory enough to allow some self-studying before actual lecture.  The pace of the class is too fast, especially when the content is really very packed.
Improvement: More explanations for each respective approach, expecting us to understand the approach fully using only 1 example (the one in slides) is not enough.

Start on the project early and do all your tutorials.

CourseDescription: Computational Thinking equips students to tackle complex computational problems; it trains students to design solutions to solve those problems using a computer program.  It draws upon concepts from mathematics and computer science – more precisely, discrete mathematics, data structures and algorithm design. This course will hone students’ analytical skills as they are challenged to think abstractly and computationally. Their minds will be open to the wonders of computing, as they go behind the scene to unravel the fundamental analytics that empower Google, consulting agencies and service companies. NOTE: To facilitate learning in this course, you are required to know and use programming.  You are advised to pick up the Python programming language before the course, for instance by practising with online tutorials such as http://learnpython.org.By taking this course, students will:• discover the science of computing • model problems and learn practical problem-solving techniques to tackle complex computational problems (beyond what a spreadsheet is capable of solving)• apply problem-solving techniques to develop more elegant and efficient programs• learn to write programs to represent and manipulate with complex data objects• understand the challenge of scale, not only in dealing with large data sets, but also in appreciating the nature of computing and computability

Experience: No standardisation for grading. Poorly managed course.

Experience: CT teaches you the most important thing when it comes to IT related work — complexity of functions and how to make them better. I bet you those who aspire to be software Engineers, both frontend and backend, are assumed to know this fundamental concept.   Other concepts they teach are very useful to know and understand, especially when you intend to go into the software engineering career path.   I took this in Year 4 so I could learn and remember these concepts closer to employment without needing to relearn. The difficulty level is the same throughout, just whether you can afford to spend an hour or two per week for the tutorial. The group project can take up some time as well so be prepared.

Experience: The SMU-X project is useful in building up your portfolio although the ICE and labs are not very related to the project. Most of the time will be spent doing the project and the skills used for the project have to learnt out of class.
Improvement: Teach half java and half spring boot instead of spending the whole semester teaching just java.
CourseDescription: This course focuses on fundamental concepts of developing programs using an object oriented approach. There will be an emphasis on writing clean and efficient code, and the ability to use an appropriate data structure or algorithm to solve problems. The Java programming language will be taught in depth.

Experience: An interesting module that may be challenging and tricky at times. The SMU-X aspect of the module provides good exposure to Java software development but may be harder for those with less development experience to keep up. However, grading seems fair enough and the weekly quizzes are crucial when it comes to scoring better grades
CourseDescription: This course focuses on fundamental concepts of developing programs using an object oriented approach. There will be an emphasis on writing clean and efficient code, and the ability to use an appropriate data structure or algorithm to solve problems. The Java programming language will be taught in depth.

Experience: Prof Yeow leong gives quizzes almost every week to test if you have grasped the concepts well but since it was a SMUX mod, would say the project was challenging and definitely needed quite a bit of teamwork
CourseDescription: This course focuses on fundamental concepts of developing programs using an object oriented approach. The Java programming language will be taught in depth.

Experience: The module really introduces coding in an applied manner with the focus of creating a working program. Recent runs of the mod have included external partners which allow for a more holistic learning experience. Expect plenty of project work
Improvement: Exams are again either disproportionately easy or difficult.
CourseDescription: This course focuses on fundamental concepts of developing programs using an object oriented approach. There will be an emphasis on writing clean and efficient code, and the ability to use an appropriate data structure or algorithm to solve problems. The Java programming language will be taught in depth.

Experience: This module is almost identical to its IS counterpart, IS442 (Object-Oriented Programming). The only difference is that this one will bridge the concept of C from CS101 (Programming Fundamentals I) with Java. With prior C knowledge, CS students should be able to understand Java pretty well.
CourseDescription: This course focuses on fundamental concepts of developing programs using an object oriented approach. There will be an emphasis on writing clean and efficient code, and the ability to use an appropriate data structure or algorithm to solve problems. The Java programming language will be taught in depth.

Experience: The lectures for the course are pretty dry (as you would expect) and the lab sessions seem to be an afterthought hastily pushed into the course to integrate "programming" with statistics by using python to perform data visualisation. However, the project was fun and engaging.
CourseDescription: This course is an introductory course in probability and statistics. It lays the mathematical foundation to prepare the students for computer science courses and their applications, in particular data science and related areas such as machine learning and artificial intelligence. The main topics covered in this course include probability, random variables, limit theorems, statistics, regression and inference, coupled with hands-on activities to illustrate their relevance to data science.

Experience: It was an interesting course, a mix of both mathematical concepts and lab sessions though a majority was the former. Python was taught to help us link to the concepts we learnt in class and mainly used for the projects.

Experience: It's a tough let's be honest HAHAHA. It teaches basic assembly code, bit manipulation and all that intense computer stuff. SUPER TECHNICAL and it made my head spin. Ok but it is an useful course esp if you're going down the CS route. It's need to know. Study hard! This mod confirm need grind one. But if u stare at it long enough and look for additional resources u should be able to get it :)
Improvement: Since it's very dry and technical, support needs to be given esp to students new to the concepts.
CourseDescription: CS106 is an introductory course in computer architecture. It aims to develop an understanding of the hardware environment upon which computing is based, and the interface it provides to higher software layers. The course also introduces basic architectures and hardware-software interfaces of embedded systems. Students will understand a computer system's functional components, their characteristics, and interactions, and acquire hands-on experiences on embedded system programming.Knowledge and experience on C programming is required.

Experience: An interesting course that broke away from the usual math & programming courses. Interesting to learn more about the hardware we use on a daily basis and lab sessions with the microbit were engaging. However, some concepts may be harder to grasp for some without prior knowledge regarding this topic.

The course also introduces basic architectures and hardware-software interfaces of embedded systems. Students will understand a computer system's functional components, their characteristics, and interactions, and acquire hands-on experiences on embedded system programming.Knowledge and experience on C programming is required.

Experience: It was a really content heavy course with many concepts to memorize. There was almost weekly graded quizzes and the topics taught we built upon each other. Very technical module in summary but it was preassigned.
CourseDescription: CS106 is an introductory course in computer architecture. Students will understand a computer system's functional components, their characteristics, and interactions, and acquire hands-on experiences on embedded system programming.Knowledge and experience on C programming is required.

Experience: Teaches basic concepts in economic stuff but which relates to software development/management practices. Really interesting for someone who wants to learn how the technology industry market works. Workload quite doable, mid term is 2 hr mcq and short answers, while finals is 1 week take home assignment. There is a group project where you are allowed to create any project you want as long as it's sellable.
Improvement: Vague grading rubrics.
CourseDescription: This course introduces students to the core concepts and skills underlying successful software product management. Students will learn about the distinct characteristics of software products vis-à-vis other industrial artefacts, and how these characteristics can be leveraged in managing the software product life cycle. With an emphasis on the elements of the software product management framework, students will acquire hands-on product management skills through classroom instruction, term projects, and presentations.

Experience: This is arguably one of the best modules to take in IS if you want to pursue a technical route. Teaches you a lot of valuable skills and knowledge used in the industry, with projects typically reflecting real-life scenarios that require practical skills. Professor Ouh is also very good at teaching and keeping class fun and interesting, and always available to answer any questions.
Improvement: Listen in class, explore the topics outside of classtime
CourseDescription: The IT Solution Architecture course integrates design concepts and methods to develop IT solutions from both the software and system-level perspectives.  It focuses on the analysis, design and implementation of an IT solution through which business requirements, software qualities and solution elements are transformed into implementable artefacts.  By combining critical analysis with hands-on design and development, the course prepares students to participate effectively in the architecture design and development stages of a software-intensive IT solution project.It is highly recommended that students are also proficient in IS442 Object Oriented Programming and Java programming language prior to reading this course.

Experience: Taken in 2020 Term 2, industry partner - Ascenda Loyalty - Free access to AWS Educate to self-learn AWS at own pace - Weekly exercises - manageable - Design Patterns 5% - Fun stuff but this is where a background in Java is useful. Taking OOP before/during your ITSA sem will help a lot.  Project is where you would likely need want to bid with a group.
Improvement: Less spam in the Official class group chat, as it might cause some students to miss important deadlines. AWS SAA Cert claiming instructions should be sent in an email instead of spamming chat.

Experience: Really good! This mod teaches you about different needs for different type of architectures of a system, think it's very useful for software engineers! This mod also provides you to get an AWS certificate, which you can flex in linkedin ;) But overall, great course taught by a great prof too!
Improvement: NIL

Experience: Best module in SMU SIS hands down. The most relevant to industry practice, especially cloud and one which I'm so glad to take! Though some may fear that the final exam is an advanced AWS solutions architect certification, I have no regrets picking it up because I used the knowledge gained for my internships.
Improvement: probably share some project management and devops tools to try out in a list!

Experience: Very good software design patterns introduced that could be adopted in future IT projects. AWS certification teaches you to deploy a scalable, maintainable and secure architecture on the cloud for your applications.

Experience: Good module overall, has good breadth and depth, touching on design principles and different cloud technologies... now also have SMU-X, able to learn how to manage sponsor requirements and handle them appropriately, can get internship too :D certificate for AWS Solutions Architect is also very useful... if you want to do well, class participation is super important, especially that bump for A- to A or A to A+ :")
Improvement: Project is a little heavy, every group puts in a lot of work so have to learn and explore more on AWS and leverage cloud services to meet the sponsor requirements, other than that, the tests and assignments are manageable

Experience: You'll learn how to actually build and deploy performant, scalable and secure applications on cloud instead of usual proof-of-concept or prototype in your other IS projects.

Experience: This used to be called Architectural Analysis. Taking this mod will help you understand how scalable computing systems work, which is how every large tech company out there works. Things like load balancing, redundancy, active/passive failovers are daily lingo in places like AWS. Thinking of working in any company that uses cloud computing? This module is vital in giving you the foundational knowledge.   I recommend moving on to professional certifications after you take this module - there are such certifications from the biggest cloud players. They will improve your employability!

Experience: I took the older Architectural Analysis Module. It was a good module which teaches you how to architect IT solutions better. The concurrency part however was really tough. You have to make sure you thoroughly understand the concepts. If you are planning to do IT Consulting, this module would teach you some valuable concepts.

Experience: Concepts are interesting - they introduce different topics from Naive Bayes to Reinforcement Learning so it helps you decide what parts of AI you like and want to take other modules on. Quizzes are manageable, assignments take some time to do, finals is difficult
Improvement: Try to get full marks-ish for the assignments because the finals are really long and difficult
CourseDescription: Artificial Intelligence (Artificial Intelligence) aims to augment or substitute human intelligence in solving complex real world decision making problems. This is a breadth course that will equip students with core concepts and practical know-how to build basic AI applications that impact business and society. Specifically, we will cover search (e.g., to schedule meetings between different people with different preferences), probabilistic graphical models (e.g. to build an AI bot that evaluates whether credit card fraud has happened based on transactions), planning and learning under uncertainty (e.g., to build AI systems that guide doctors in recommending medicines for patients or taxi drivers to "right" places at the "right" times to earn more revenue), multi-agent systems (e.g., to build next generation patrolling systems for critical infrastructure security), image processing (e.g. to build systems that track and/or recognize suspicious people) and natural language processing (e.g., to build chat bots that can automatically and intelligently interact with customers in different service industries).

Experience: I find the contents too difficult to understand especially if you are very weak in probability. Not enough practices were given to prepare us for quizzes or assignments. It is like taking CT but 3x the difficulty. Some concepts from CT apply here which is a plus, but other than that it was too draining to study for this module.
Improvement: I hope that more practices will be provided for future cohorts. Some examples in the slides lack answers as well, which really doesn't aid in studying
CourseDescription: Artificial Intelligence (Artificial Intelligence) aims to augment or substitute human intelligence in solving complex real world decision making problems. This is a breadth course that will equip students with core concepts and practical know-how to build basic AI applications that impact business and society. Specifically, we will cover search (e.g., to schedule meetings between different people with different preferences), probabilistic graphical models (e.g. to build an AI bot that evaluates whether credit card fraud has happened based on transactions), planning and learning under uncertainty (e.g., to build AI systems that guide doctors in recommending medicines for patients or taxi drivers to "right" places at the "right" times to earn more revenue), multi-agent systems (e.g., to build next generation patrolling systems for critical infrastructure security), image processing (e.g. to build systems that track and/or recognize suspicious people) and natural language processing (e.g., to build chat bots that can automatically and intelligently interact with customers in different service industries).

Experience: Recommend taking this course first before starting on another track course, if you're in the AI track. Prof Pradeep is engaging during his class and does make an effort to take some time to recap the previous lesson, which is really helpful. You should be comfortable with coding by now (Python) - you will be expected to quickly build programs (like a blackjack game) to base your AI agent on as part of assignments (which is not something taught in class). You would also need to have decent math and stats fundamentals. This is a good course to find out what you like and help you choose your other 3 AI track courses.
Improvement: Definitely need more exercise questions with answers. There is not enough practice questions to prepare for the exams. Some questions do not have a model answer, which can be frustrating when you are not sure where you go wrong.

Specifically, we will cover search (e.g., to schedule meetings between different people with different preferences), probabilistic graphical models (e.g. to build an AI bot that evaluates whether credit card fraud has happened based on transactions), planning and learning under uncertainty (e.g., to build AI systems that guide doctors in recommending medicines for patients or taxi drivers to "right" places at the "right" times to earn more revenue), multi-agent systems (e.g., to build next generation patrolling systems for critical infrastructure security), image processing (e.g. to build systems that track and/or recognize suspicious people) and natural language processing (e.g., to build chat bots that can automatically and intelligently interact with customers in different service industries).

Experience: This was a really interesting class that gave a very good introduction to the field of AI. Those who are still unsure if they should take AI can take this course, to get a good idea of what to expect! Exams/Quizzes are of reasonable difficulty, assignments are very heavy and difficult but really help to reinforce the concepts learnt in class.
Improvement: NIL, thought that there was adequate guidance and resources provided along the way.

Experience: Amazing prof. The class ranged from basic Probabilities, to Bayesian Networks (some lameass model), to tensor flow, and RL. And the assignment basically force you to try everyone of them. Legit learnt a lot.

Experience: This module is very useful if you are in AI track, it covers everything from the things you will learn in your elective. The learning curve is steep but it's manageable once you get the concept. But the finals are tough, try to score well for your assignments and quiz

Experience: Most useful module i took in SMU but the learning curve can be steep if this is the first few analytics module that you are taking as it involves a lot of mathematics and knowledge about analytics. The exam is also relatively difficult with many questions and little time to do but overall very useful module whether you are taking Artifical Intelligence or Business Analytics as your major
Improvement: Can have more hands-on practice
CourseDescription: Machine Learning is one of the fundamental subjects in the field of Artificial Intelligence. Machine Learning is concerned with computer programs that automatically improve their performance through experience (e.g., learning to recognize image or speech, classify text documents, detect credit card frauds, or drive autonomous vehicles).  This course covers both fundamental theory and practical algorithms for machine learning from a variety of perspectives. It includes a range of topics, from supervised learning (such as classification and regression) to unsupervised learning (such as clustering), and from traditional (shallow) learning (such as support vector machine) to recent state-of-the-art deep learning methods. The course is intended to prepare students for basic understanding of machine learning fundamentals and equip students with capability of applied machine learning techniques for real applications.Students are strongly encouraged to have proficiency in IS103 Computational Thinking prior to reading this course.  NOTE: While this is an introduction course, it is a technical course and it is highly recommended that students are proficient in programming, probabilities, statistics and linear algebra (e.g., CS103 Linear Algebra for Computing Applications, CS105 Statistical Thinking for Data Science, CS201 Data Structures and Algorithms and CS202 Design and Analysis of Algorithms).

Experience: Really good experience taking this mod. Learned a lot with regards to machine learning. Although it only covers the basic concepts of it, it was really interesting and a great introduction to machine learning!
Improvement: More labs!

Experience: A bit more calculations to learn and do as compared to DM but once you understand it you will do fine! It would help if you take DM first before ML since ML is a bit more difficult or you can also take it concurrently if you think you can handle learning a few more calculations.
Improvement: None that I can think of right now since the prof was super friendly and helpful :)
CourseDescription: Machine Learning is one of the fundamental subjects in the field of Artificial Intelligence. Machine Learning is concerned with computer programs that automatically improve their performance through experience (e.g., learning to recognize image or speech, classify text documents, detect credit card frauds, or drive autonomous vehicles).  This course covers both fundamental theory and practical algorithms for machine learning from a variety of perspectives. It includes a range of topics, from supervised learning (such as classification and regression) to unsupervised learning (such as clustering), and from traditional (shallow) learning (such as support vector machine) to recent state-of-the-art deep learning methods. The course is intended to prepare students for basic understanding of machine learning fundamentals and equip students with capability of applied machine learning techniques for real applications.Students are strongly encouraged to have proficiency in IS103 Computational Thinking prior to reading this course.  NOTE: While this is an introduction course, it is a technical course and it is highly recommended that students are proficient in programming, probabilities, statistics and linear algebra (e.g., CS103 Linear Algebra for Computing Applications, CS105 Statistical Thinking for Data Science, CS201 Data Structures and Algorithms and CS202 Design and Analysis of Algorithms).

Experience: I wouldnt call this module introductory. If you go in with just analytics foundation experience, you will find this mod a struggle. The content is very math heavy.

Experience: You will learn alot from this module, but be prepared to camp in school because you would need GPU to run the assignment and Google Colab GPU is not that powerful to handle the dataset.
CourseDescription: When we see a table, we  vividly perceive it as an object in the class of tables.  However, computers only see a bunch of pixels. Image perception is the task of getting computers to see in a human like manner. To achieve this, researchers have pooled techniques and results from a large variety of different fields.This course introduces the mathematical tools and concepts underlying image perception. These include deep learning, linear algebra, statistics and multi-view geometry. The goal is to get students comfortable with utilizing and interpreting the results of state-of-art machine learning techniques. At the end of the course, students should be aware of what can be achieved by current visual perception techniques, how to achieve it and what the limitations of these techniques are. Students are expected to have a good mathematical foundation and programing skills. Foundational Mathematical Courses (i.e., CS103 or CS105) will be an advantage but are not insisted on. The primary programing language of the course is python.

Experience: Prof is generally fair, and mostly helpful in answering questions promptly (via piazza). This class involves quite abit of coding (Netlogo) while touching across a broad array of topics, from search algorithms to game theory. Those without background for the later topics (esp game theory) might find the learning curve steep. This is balanced out with the quiz being open book, and there being no exam. Quizzes includes coding as well. However, project work can be quite heavy or light, depending on your scope (It is pretty much an open topic for project). It does help to keep your project scope manageable (easier to code and find data/facts on). Start early, and the project should be pretty manageable. .
Improvement: Feedback could be elaborated more - sometimes its unclear where you went wrong in assignments.
CourseDescription: In this course, we introduce agent-based modeling and simulation (ABMS) as an approach for studying complex business and social processes. With examples from domains such as transportation, economics, finance, and urban planning, we show how ABMS can help us better understand complex business and social phenomena. ABMS systems are particularly powerful if we want to describe a system populated by many independent and heterogeneous decision makers (who can be collaborators or competitors). ABMS systems can also be used in performing policy evaluations and generating decision supports, as we can then computationally test how changes in parameters at different levels would affect various performance indicators. Besides covering theoretic foundations of ABMS, we focus heavily on hands-on learning as well. In particular, we will expose students to NetLogo, an intuitive yet powerful modeling language for building ABMS systems. We will be learning NetLogo by building several classical ABMS examples incrementally in class. Objectives Upon successful completion of this course, a student will be able to: • Understand what is an ABMS. • Evaluate the pros and cons of using an ABMS system in describing selected real-world phenomena. • Utilize ABMS systems in policy/strategy evaluations. • Appreciate the importance of considering uncertainty and opponent modeling when designing strategic, tactic, and operational policies. • Complete the full cycle of building an ABMS system using the NetLogo programming language:  o Design an ABMS system with a proper level of granularity and fidelity (defining agents and means of communications).  o Validate and calibrate the built ABMS.   o Interpret the outcome of the ABMS system.

Experience: Provides me with all the fundamentals such as public key security, certification processes and basic web security.
CourseDescription: The Foundations of Cybersecurity course provides fundamental knowledge and technical skills for protecting computing and networking systems against various cyber-attacks. Topics covered include cryptographic algorithms, public key infrastructure, network security, authentication, access control, web security basics, and malware basics.  Classroom instructions will be integrated with hands-on exercises and group projects.

Experience: This is an interesting module, but the prof just make the experience bad
CourseDescription: Built on the foundation of the Information Security and Trust course (IS302), this course draws on hard-won experience to explain the latest developments in security protocols, network security, web security, application security and industrial standards. Classroom instruction and discussion will closely integrate technical principles with real world applications such as secure e-banking, secure corporate networking, secure messaging in healthcare environment and multimedia system security. In addition, case studies will be used to demonstrate that security and trust are not only for protection of information assets, but also means of improving business operation or even starting new businesses. Besides the textbook knowledge, this course also brings to the classroom security practices in industries, e.g. Microsoft, and government agencies (e.g IRAS and CSIT).

Experience: Project is really difficult. Take home assignments must do some self research to score. Very very difficult to score. However, if you're in Cyber Security track, you might have to take this mod. Try to avoid if possible. Protect your grades.

He will answer your questions no matter how silly it is without judgement. Grade wise it is quite daunting, as 70% of the total grade is from labs. Labs are pretty doable, I recommend trying out some scenarios that you think might come out for labs cause that helps me get through the labs with decent grades.
Improvement: Content-wise the depth is not that deep. Might be more interesting to have more theories as well instead of only practice.
CourseDescription: Software and systems security aims in equipping students with the fundamental concepts in software and systems security, as well as basic hands-on skills in understanding, analyzing, and protecting a software program and a computer system. Each lesson spends roughly 50% of the time on fundamental concepts (lecturing) and 50% of the time on hands-on exercises/assessments. Assessments focus on hands-on projects.

Experience: This mod is quite heavy, to be honest. You must study and review again and again. There's not many exercises to practice with also. The quizzes are dreadful because they make up the most of the weightage.

Class participation is actually quite crucial in this module (or maybe depending on the professor in-charge).  Theory (in some weeks) are very dry and heavy. Also, concepts can be very new to CS/IS students due to the introduction of hardware and electronical components.  Highly recommended to take under Prof Pius :)
Improvement: Be shameless :) Participate in the class sharing! Buy your CPS parts early
CourseDescription: Cyber-Physical Systems infuse sensing, computing, networking, and control capabilities into physical objects, breathing into them new life, new purpose, and new meaning. They are present in diverse application domains: social services, food, healthcare, transportation, environmental sustainability, and more. Cyber-Physical Systems empower global communities to create meaningful impact by addressing societal challenges, in areas such as social fabric, quality of life, and sustainability.In this foundational course, we embark on an adventure; sometimes challenging, always exciting. We learn vital theories, acquire skills, and work with tools for Cyber-Physical Systems. We discover their essential elements. We explore ways to unite the cyber and physical realms. We unleash our creative energies, our youthful idealism, and our capacity to dream, by creating visionary technology to conquer a real-world societal challenge. The adventure reaches its peak at the project showcase, where we witness the work of human hands come to fruition, leaving us inspired to reflect deeply and broadly about how we, as global citizens, can harness the power of Cyber-Physical Systems as a potent force in the service of humanity.

Experience: Excited to learn how to build android apps but warning you need to self learn alot depending on your project scope. Marking scheme ain't clear or quite vague, so it's hard to understand why marks lost.
Improvement: Improve the marking scheme and teach more android programming stuff instead of mobile concepts
CourseDescription: This course aims to introduce the concept of mobile and pervasive technologies to the students while providing hands-on experience in building such systems. The focus will be mainly on the concepts of (i) mobile/pervasive computing and application development, (ii) applications of mobile systems, (iii) context-awareness, and (iv) improving usability and efficiency of mobile applications. The course examines the outline provided above, from both technical and real-world applications, hence involves the concepts of machine learning. Students of this class will be using development tools and techniques to build mobile Applications (using Android OS) and the main focus will be on making mobile applications faster (lower-latency), more energy-efficient, smarter (context-aware) and highly usable (multimodal UIs).

Experience: Can learn how to code in Android Studio. Good for widening of knowledge. But don't know how to score well because there isn't a marking scheme.

Be prepared to spend hours every week in order to complete the deliverables and ensuring that the prototype is working well. There are times when what the client wants does not match with the project module requirements, so it was hard trying to determine what is expected for the project.

Students will learn how to:identify and translate real needs into system requirements and constraintsidentify suitable IoT technologies to realize a practical system; andbuild simple proof-of-concept applications, through real-world examplesStudents may also find some background/skills in interactive design and prototyping useful (e.g., IS211 Interaction Design and Prototyping).

Experience: IoT is a SMU-X module, so you work with real companies. The 2020T1 project was with NEA\MSE on the Tray Return Campaign. We explore how tray return rate can be calculated more efficiently with the help of IoT sensors, each team was given a budget $180 to buy sensors and Wi-Fi routers. Each team consists of 5 members, and safe to say that each member will be provided with at least 1 Raspberry Pi 3 to play around.   We used round force sensors in our set up and it meant that we have to solder a resistor to the sensors as well. This was not taught in the module.  At the deployment area, there are constraints like: - we have to deploy when it is not during popular meal times (breakfast, lunch etc.) - problem of limited power sockets
Improvement: I don't recommend taking SMU-X modules during the Covid period when all classes are online. Also, it would be good to check with the prof regarding what is the SMU-X project scope in advance before even bidding for the module.

Improvement: Practice more and understand the concepts well. It would be good if practice questions in class can be more challenging.
CourseDescription: This course will cover the fundamentals of relational database theory, important data management concepts such as data modelling, database design, database implementation and searches in un-structured data (i.e., text) in current business information systems for non-SCIS students. A series of in-class exercises, tests, pop quiz and course project will help students understand covered topics. Students are expected to apply knowledge learned in the classroom to solve many problems based upon real-life business scenarios, while gaining hands-on experiences in designing, implementing, and managing database systems.

Experience: The course contents are quite useful. Introducing a lot of concepts about database system and some basic MySQL operations. The project really helped me to understand the course contents better. But the grading is quite cruel so please be prepared...
Improvement: I think some real world designs of the database system can be introduced to the class... but don't know if it's possible

Experience: I took IS111 under jiang jing and joelle. Coming from a jc kid, I find python quite challenging and it really takes time to pick up and master it well. The lab tests were very challenging and usually could only solve 1 star questions, it is kind of demoralising to be less than average but I would say programming is very dependent on familiarity and logic.  This course is very practical at the least, and the profs and TAs are very friendly and try to help out as much as possible. What I hope is they will give out the correct codes immediately after class but sometimes they don't even give out the answers which makes it difficult to learn. The class part is mostly answering questions like what is 2**2**3 or debugging the codes and pointing out errors.  Overall, really gained new skills over here!
Improvement: Try your best to do the in-class exercises and labs!
CourseDescription: This course is intended for any student who wishes to gain some programming fundamentals, also known as the building blocks of Information Systems. The course introduces students to fundamental programming concepts and constructs, explains the process of developing a basic software application, and explains the basic concepts of object orientation. The student will experience the implementation of a basic software application. Python, a widely-used, high-level, general-purpose and interactive programming language, is used as the vehicle of exploration in this course.

Experience: For me, it was a struggle of picking up Python when I first started. However, I slowly learnt to enjoy coding as time passes. Each week, there will be a new theory to be learnt and added to your coding knowledge. It is very important for you to be able to understand and apply them when coding. TAs and prof are really kind and helpful source for you to clarify doubts and ask questions. There are different level of difficulties for all the in-class exercises, class quizzes, lab tests and final exams: 1-star, 2-star and 3-star. 1-star and 2-star are manageable but 3-star questions are very challenging. In my opinion, i feel that if the lab tests are set slightly more challenging to score, final exam tends to be more doable to compensate for the grade.
Improvement: Keep practising the questions given. That is the only way you can remember all the contents learnt and code proficiently.
CourseDescription: This course is intended for any student who wishes to gain some programming fundamentals, also known as the building blocks of Information Systems. The course introduces students to fundamental programming concepts and constructs, explains the process of developing a basic software application, and explains the basic concepts of object orientation. The student will experience the implementation of a basic software application. Python, a widely-used, high-level, general-purpose and interactive programming language, is used as the vehicle of exploration in this course.

Experience: Really enjoyed this mod. Not an IS student but I took this mod to further improve my programming skills. Recommend to take in sem 2 if you are a non IS student. I had zero background in programming before starting but it is good to watch some online videos or courses to understand the basics of python. To do well, it is EXTREMELY important to practice and practice. Make sure you understand each week's content as all of it is built up as you progress. For lab tests and exams, it is sufficient to be able to do well by completing 1/2 star questions. 3 star questions are really challenging and for those who want to attain A and above. It is important to make sure you do all the lab homework yourself and try to understand what is wrong with your code. The TAs and prof are really friendly and there to help, so do ask them if you need to.
Improvement: NIL

The 3-star questions are challenging and I found it pretty hard (if not impossible) to solve most of them but they are not needed to do well on the course. Overall it is a great introductory course to python.
Improvement: More practice for finals. Giving suggestions on how we can further improve python skills and practise and learn further.
CourseDescription: This course is intended for any student who wishes to gain some programming fundamentals, also known as the building blocks of Information Systems. The course introduces students to fundamental programming concepts and constructs, explains the process of developing a basic software application, and explains the basic concepts of object orientation. The student will experience the implementation of a basic software application. Python, a widely-used, high-level, general-purpose and interactive programming language, is used as the vehicle of exploration in this course.

Experience: I learnt Python just before school started, so I had some headstart. I generally found what is being taught manageable and easy enough to understand, but difficult to master without consistent practice.   I found the lab tests generally manageable, but the questions at the end can get quite challenging. For example, for LT2 2021, one of the questions at the back took about 60 lines for me to solve (was very lucky to solve it). I would strongly advise people to return None or empty list for questions they cannot do, as they might award some marks for doing so. The lab tests are generally not easy to score past 20/25 for each of them (not giveaways). I strongly recommend people learn how to use the debugger on Visual Studio code themselves, and also how to debug in general. Also, checking after each step by using the print function is very useful and time-saving, as it avoids the need to find the bugs in the code which can be very difficult and stressful under timed conditions. I really advise people to do all the practice questions and past lab test questions, as they can really help in building up problem-solving skills.   For the finals, for my semester (2021-22 Sem 1), it was much more manageable than the lab test, but was slightly tricky. Each question is not too long or complex, and most of my friends managed to attempt almost every question. The downside of finals is that code cannot be run, so mistakes may be made unknowingly (idk how many mistakes I accidentally made). So maybe code more slowly?? Consensus is that finals are easier and meant to pull overall grades up.   Quizzes are pop quizzes which means that they suddenly appear. There were 4 pop up quizzes throughout my semester. Questions are either MCQ, predict the output, multi-select, and paper coding. Paper coding only appeared for the last quiz for my prof.  Lastly, I realised that it is very useful to learn outside the syllabus, especially list and dictionary comprehension. They drastically decrease the number of lines needed to be written and can solve the problems more elegantly. More practice is needed to be able to confidently apply it in exams to save time.
Improvement: More emphasis on paper coding. The final exam is about paper coding, but yet I find that there is not enough emphasis on coding correctly without being able to run the program. It is way easier to make coding mistakes when paper coding than what people think. More specialised coaching sessions should be provided to students that need it, as it is easy to fall behind. For the lab tests, the prof should also cover using the debugger and how to debug, as it can be very nerve-wracking during the lab tests if this happens.

The course introduces students to fundamental programming concepts and constructs, explains the process of developing a basic software application, and explains the basic concepts of object orientation. The student will experience the implementation of a basic software application. Python, a widely-used, high-level, general-purpose and interactive programming language, is used as the vehicle of exploration in this course.

Experience: tbh a very easy mod to take, take up an edx python course beforehand and you can def pass through this mod with ease. Very individual mod as well without the project part, probably the hardest contribution would only be the class part factor.
Improvement: nothing much to be improved, very easy skill to pick its just the basics.

Experience: One of the first foundational mods to take into the journey of SCIS, I often find myself going to back refer to the stuff I've learnt from this module because it's really the fundamentals. The module can be challenging for those who have never learned programming beforehand but it's definitely a good kind of challenge.
Improvement: I think that lab test questions are rigorous enough but when it comes to solution-wise, it can be very touch and go, could afford to go more in-depth with the explanations.

Experience: This course has many good professors and TAs who will really guide you if you are new to coding. The bell curve also does help a lot if you do not score well for the lab test. In general, I think that it's quite manageable if you put in the time and effort to do the exercises.
Improvement: Sometimes I find that the ICE can be much easier than the questions in the lab test.

Experience: My professor is Michelle Kan. During class time, she gives clear instructions to us and designs sets of In-class exercises that use the specific set of syntax for that week's lesson. Extra practices are also given. As for exams, the lab tests are of higher standard than the exercises given, so please continue practising even after the class has been ended.  P.S. This module has no bell curve, so don't hesitate to earn what you want (answer questions actively during class, volunteer to share ICE answers, etc).
Improvement: Maybe include more practice questions of exam standard inside ICE

Experience: This is basic python coding, prof teaches you the fundamental concepts and you have to be creative and utilise that knowledge to code according to the question/situation given. It is a really useful mod since coding is a up and coming skill to have.   It is competitive since you will be graded with people with coding background, naturally they can code faster and more efficiently. However, TAs and Profs are always there readily to offer guidance when you need help.   If you do not have coding background like me, we need to work a little extra harder than the rest who have background. Keep practicing!

The TA will offer insights on how to better write your code.

CourseDescription: This course will cover fundamentals of relational database theory, important data management concepts such as data modelling, database design, database implementation in current business information systems, and some basic concepts related to unstructured data.A series of in-class exercises, tests, pop quizzes and a course project will help students understand the covered topics. Students are expected to apply knowledge learned in the classroom to solve many problems based on real-life business scenarios, while gaining hands-on experience in designing, implementing, and managing database systems. Students are also expected to understand the differences between structured data and unstructured data.This course is applicable to students declaring a major from SIS.

Experience: it is an interesting mod , where SQL is taught! It was neatly organised and clearly taught by the profs! As long as we listen in class and do the exercises properly , you'll be fine. The lab test was pretty tricky tho!
Improvement: nil
CourseDescription: This course will cover fundamentals of relational database theory, important data management concepts such as data modelling, database design, database implementation in current business information systems, and some basic concepts related to unstructured data.A series of in-class exercises, tests, pop quizzes and a course project will help students understand the covered topics. Students are expected to apply knowledge learned in the classroom to solve many problems based on real-life business scenarios, while gaining hands-on experience in designing, implementing, and managing database systems. Students are also expected to understand the differences between structured data and unstructured data.This course is applicable to students declaring a major from SIS.

Experience: As a pre-assigned course, this gives students a solid foundational understanding of how a database works and SQL. The instructors are very knowledgeable and go above and beyond to clarify any student doubts, even organizing additional weekly supplementary lessons.
Improvement: One can feel that the practice exercises given are insufficient and it is against school policy to try past year papers or discuss them with instructors/profs. Students will need to find additional practices online if they require it.

Experience: Good module. Everything was super well organized, prof and instructors go above and beyond in providing students the support needed to pass and excel. Definitely a cornerstone of the SCIS education path, SQL is an essential skill in a large part of IT and this course does it justice by giving a clear, practical introduction to it.  The exams are not easy. Take note that the last 3-4 questions are NOT commensurate with the level of the in-class/after-class exercises. You will want to get some serious practice if you want to do well in this course.
Improvement: Project can be less dry! It is purely technical SQL and diagram work.

Improvement: Personally, I feel that this module should implement project same as WAD2 (this shall be a server-side rendering webpage project as students do not know js yet) so that students can solidify their learning so that they can feel the impact of what they can do with the language with SQL + also can act as a school portfolio for them in their early years, if I not wrong the first school portfolio they can have is in WAD2 which is the next semester. Maybe a simple project outline will do as if I am not wrong they are taking IS112: DATA MANAGEMENT concurrently which can be heavy for them

Improvement: Exam questions can be tedious, instead of difficult? And the topics can be a bit dry if you don't have an engaging professor. But you will be pre-assigned so not much you can do about this anyway.

CourseDescription: With the emergence of new technologies and evolution of existing ones, organizations are changing the way they build enterprise solutions. Rather than build monolithic applications, the current emphasis is on building solutions by leveraging existing functionality exposed as services (a.k.a API). This approach to composing solutions using services follows the Service Oriented Architecture (SOA) paradigm, where applications are structured as a collection of loosely coupled services. In this course students will learn how to design and implement enterprise solutions using SOA using enterprise tools. The course will cover topics such as cloud computing, SOA, Enterprise Service Bus (ESB), XML, web services and micro-services architecture.

Experience: It was an enriching module that taught useful concepts while making good use of projects to apply and practise the use of microservices to build a complete solution. All in all, a good experience as a technical module.
Improvement: The practicals could have been gone through more thoroughly
CourseDescription: With the emergence of new technologies and evolution of existing ones, organizations are changing the way they build enterprise solutions. Rather than build monolithic applications, the current emphasis is on building solutions by leveraging existing functionality exposed as services (a.k.a API). This approach to composing solutions using services follows the Service Oriented Architecture (SOA) paradigm, where applications are structured as a collection of loosely coupled services. In this course students will learn how to design and implement enterprise solutions using SOA using enterprise tools. The course will cover topics such as cloud computing, SOA, Enterprise Service Bus (ESB), XML, web services and micro-services architecture.

Experience: Great opportunity to learn and understand the new microservices architecture that is being implemented in many of today's applications and systems. I took Chris Poskitt and he's the best prof I have ever taken due to the fact that he knows how to entertain his class and get everyone's attention without making it awkward.
Improvement: I believe that the project can have some restrictions (?) to make it more fair in the marking criteria.

Improvement: There is no proper marking rubrics for the project and because of this it is very difficult to know what could be improved especially when you thought your project was above average yet the grading doesn't reflect that.
CourseDescription: With the emergence of new technologies and evolution of existing ones, organizations are changing the way they build enterprise solutions. Rather than build monolithic applications, the current emphasis is on building solutions by leveraging existing functionality exposed as services (a.k.a API). This approach to composing solutions using services follows the Service Oriented Architecture (SOA) paradigm, where applications are structured as a collection of loosely coupled services. In this course students will learn how to design and implement enterprise solutions using SOA using enterprise tools. The course will cover topics such as cloud computing, SOA, Enterprise Service Bus (ESB), XML, web services and micro-services architecture.

Experience: Project heavy module, but I learned a lot along the way. This is a useful module that has prepared me for the industry. Final is moderately difficult. The lessons can be very theory and dry, but they're important concepts to know for the industry.
Improvement: NA

Experience: We mainly learn about (micro)services vs monolith applications and how to write them. Its interesting how different the approaches are and the possibilities available. also the exam requires writing 'debates' of why you would prefer one solution over the other (both given by question), those kinda questions and more.
Improvement: idk, but i think the exam requires strong understanding to really score

Improvement: nil

Experience: Pretty fun to explore different APIs and applying to the business scenario during project. In general, the quizzes and assignments are doable and not tough so long as you pay attention in class and understand the concepts. The project can be tough but can make reference from lab exercises, so just need to decipher the lab code then apply it accordingly. Understanding is more important than blindly copying.
Improvement: Peer evaluation should be enabled for this module, felt unfair to tank majority of the project codes. Taking along with ESM, the workload can be intense and rush especially with project mates that did not contribute much other than memorising and presentation skills.

Improvement: Please don't make us take ESM and ESD together. It took a big toll on my mental health and I'm not exaggerating.
