Experience: 1. Course content is not structured well 2. Slides are terribly difficult to understand 3. Proper understanding of usefulness of course happens in week12  If you want to score in this course:  1. Book consult with your prof like every week 2. This course is about DevOps, and how we can support the DevOps process. Learn more about that before diving into this course.  3. Workload is fairly manageable. Bid with your friends.
Improvement: 1. Improve the quality of the slides. Make sure terms are consistent across the slides, and leave the meaningless diagrams out.  2. Include useful diagrams that show the flow of processes. Keep the terms CONSISTENT throughout the slides.
CourseDescription: This course explores the elements in the IT ecosystem that is required to support enterprise systems. It is divided into three main areas: maintenance, change and disaster prevention and recovery. Using common tools in the industry for ticketing, automated testing and DevOps, students are given hands-on experience as well as the understanding for robust delivery, efficient change and deep resilience. Teams will be given their own  system environment to maintain and protect. Real world use cases and examples are given to highlight the importance and complexity of managing applications in the enterprise.

Experience: This module theory portion is to aid the management side of the project, however, for the technical portion, there is too little content that is covered and sufficient enough for students to do the project. A lot of self-learning has to be done for it.  For the project, try not to use seniors architecture as prof will know lol, if you wanna use, make sure u really understand what is going on with the build / set up.  If your team is not technically proficient, tbh not all is lost, it is still a management module as implied by the title, make sure you can improve on the management side of things as tbh I feel without management, you cannot perform the technical side of things well/structured manner.  Overall, this module really throws you into the ocean if you do not have a cloud background, however, you will learn a lot from it
Improvement: Maybe allow students to take up AWS cloud practitioner cert as part of the module so that everyone knows what's up and won't be blind when doing their self-research

Experience: This course sometimes feels like two different courses combined into one as the theory part is straightforward but when we are doing the project work it feels like we are being thrown to the wolves with barely enough information. The work we do for the project involves AWS which we are left to discover for ourselves. This would not be so bad if we do not have to study ESM theory concurrently. The project feels so out of left field of everything else, as the skills we have to learn to do it isn't the topic taught to us in class.
Improvement: There is a serious need to restructure this mod as the workload and dissemination of course materials feels very disorganized. Some material has to be accessed from only the ESM website, some are in google drive links that have to be accessed from e-learn, some are in Microsoft Teams.

Improvement: The workload, the workload, the workload! And the baseline knowledge to tackle them would be useful for beginners with shells!

Experience: This module gave me anxiety and felt that the project phases started way too late in week 7 and you have to cramp everything within the next 5-6 weeks. Only basic AWS EC2 are taught during labs whereas for project wise, you have to start early and plan out what you want to implement and research a lot before the actual project start else you will have countless sleepless night because of the project.
Improvement: Clear instructions about project to be given to class before project phases begins as you will get penalty if you dont manage your stakeholder/communication well which was not very emphasized to the class.

For people who bid in relatively big numbers, please be nice and understanding to your team mates.

This module is really tough and you need a lot of mental resilience to get through it.

Experience: The course was interesting with a lot of practical aspects to managing an enterprise's systems, although they were very surface level stuff. The project work was the main source of hardship, as you need to be on the ball with any software attacks the professors dole out and even have some sleepless nights creating/strengthening/maintaining your systems for a few weeks.
Improvement: The project needs to bear in mind that there are people who have had zero experience with such software and possibly provide us with a range of software to use in the project in order to provide an equal playing field.

Experience: In summary, this is one of the one of the worst modules I took so far as a 2nd Year IS student. The expectations of the module vs. the reality of it through the project is drastic. Experience in cloud technologies, networking concepts, how to create and manage a server is INSANELY ADVANTAGEOUS.   Recommendation to juniors: Do not overload the semester with other tough module. ESM, ESD and DBTT are likely to be taken together; all 3 have considerable amount of quizzes, assignments and projects. Deadlines are back-to-back for project submission. (Seek more advice from seniors for clarification.)  Read below to find out what is bad: For the classes, they teach the bare minimum for technology concepts — like networking — and how to use cloud technologies — like Amazon EC2. However, for the project, we are expected to know how to use things like CIDR blocks, private subnets, scripts and come up with an insane architecture to achieve that 'A' grade. Their teaching on how to use Linux CLI is so minimal, then they expect us to trawl through the entire Amazon EC2 image they provided to clean up the entire EC2 instance.  Given what I explained, the professors get 'upset' when we seek help from seniors., and I quote "your seniors are making too much noise". Furthermore, they also discourage sharing between peers and create a toxic and competitive environment that make teams try to out-do each other for that extra edge over the rest.

Experience: Content in class and what you do in project is 2 separate worlds. You learn about support management in class, but project is about handling a servers, which will NOT be taught in class, nor will it be taught during consults. It will heavily depend on your own group's abilities. Little to no consults or questions were allowed to be asked and there was a lot of self-learning. It will get competitive and stressful so just be prepared.

CourseDescription: Organizations can develop competitive edge through exploitation of digital technologies namely cloud computing, big data and analytics, mobile networks, social media, and the Internet of Things. By effectively leveraging these technologies they can go beyond boosting efficiency and drive new business models, develop new revenue streams, or drive other material changes that lead to an increase in the top or bottom lines. A number of companies such as Amazon, Netflix, Uber, GE, Nike etc. have successfully managed to transform their business to digital business.The “Digital Business: Technologies & Transformation” course will help the students understand the fundamentals of the digital technologies and the principles and practices that lead to successful digital transformation. Improvement: More applicable skills, practicals, and projects.

Experience: There's been some controversy regarding this module where people say it's useless and why is this even a module in SCIS but I really enjoyed my learning in this module. It's an eye-opening module that looks at the bigger perspective of things.

Experience: Interesting course, covers the basics of analytics. Slides are very low effort, need to self study using external resources to grasp a good understanding of the topics. Lab test was a disaster — must be very familiar with Pandas and go beyond the examples in the homework.
Improvement: Clarify doubts early. Practice using Pandas in your own time with public datasets to get a good understanding of how the language works.
CourseDescription: Analytics Foundation is a foundation course that must be taken by all students pursuing the Analytics 2nd Major. This course aims to build an understanding of concepts needed to find analytical solutions to real world problems. This will cover topics including an introduction to Analytics, statistical concepts, tools for exploring and cleaning big data sets and prepare them for analysis. Coursework will include a wide variety of case studies and hands on exercises drawn from applications of analytics in multiple industries to demonstrate the complexity and benefits of analytics across different fields and domains.

Experience: No exams mod, some people find it heavy, i think it's pretty ok, easy to pass too.
CourseDescription: In this globalising and competitive business environment, the value of location as a business measure is fast becoming an important consideration for organisation.  GIS with its capability to capture, manage, display, and analyse business information spatially is emerging as a location intelligence tool.   Today, many kinds of industries are employing GIS as an integral part of their business processes.  Examples of the use of GIS in business are: • Market Analysis Which is the company’s market share in different geographical areas?  Where are the customers located?  What are the characteristics of customers in different geographical locations?  Are there potential customers and where do they live?   • Site Selection Where are the shops or branches of the company located today?  Where are the competitors located?  What would be the surrounding market area for a new location?  What are the socio-economic characteristics of the people living in this market area?  Will the establishment of a new shop interfere with the existing shop owned by the company?  Are the land prices in different areas suitable for building a new shop? • Sales territories Which the company’s present division into sales territories?  What kind of customers live in these districts and how much is sold?  Is there a need for more salesmen in any district?  Could redistricting lead to more efficient sales organisation and less travelling time for the salesmen? • Distribution and travel costs How can the distribution system be made more efficient?  In what way does the transport system influence the distribution and how does it restrict or facilitate expansion in the region?  Can the number of journeys made by company staff be reduced by applying route planning software?  Are there any alternatives to our present distribution system?  • Analysis of the global environment and new export markets What is the general economic and spatial pattern in the region?  How good is the infrastructure?  How is the population distributed geographically?  Which other companies are present in the region and where are they located?  Is this region a potential export market for the company’s products?  This course provides students with an introduction to practical applications of GIS in business operations. Emphasis will be placed on (i) locating, acquiring and integrating business data into GIS, (ii) understand the principles and methodologies of the geocoding process, (iii) become familiar with geovisualisation, spatial analysis and location modelling techniques, and (iv) explore the technologies and possibilities of server-based and/or web-based GIS analysis for Business Intelligence.

Experience: SMU-X Project Module! Quite a heavy module, there are 3 take home exercises + 1 project. Gives you access to QGIS and DataCamp to learn about various geospatial analytics functions in R. Got exposed to geospatial data handling, spatial clustering, spatial point patterns etc.

Experience: Learnt a lot from the slides although I had to self study a bit since the prof tends to side track and share about his stories (which are also pretty interesting btw). Preparing the summary to submit at the start of class helps with the revision of the content
Improvement: The slides content can be more organised
CourseDescription: The Financial Services Industry was among the early adopters of IT, achieving cost efficiencies and increased revenues through new opportunities enabled by IT.    This course introduces the banking environment and architecture. It delves into some of the key processes that span the front and back office of a bank and the associated banking products that provide IT solutions to enable these processes.    These include core banking and payment systems as well as delivery channels such as ATM, internet and mobile devices.    Topics such as banking security, customer insights, emerging technologies and industry trends will also be covered.

Experience: Chill mod with no finals, but every week you gotta do some pre-class homework that is graded. Also project kinda lame and waste of time

It delves into some of the key processes that span the front and back office of a bank and the associated banking products that provide IT solutions to enable these processes.    These include core banking and payment systems as well as delivery channels such as ATM, internet and mobile devices.    Topics such as banking security, customer insights, emerging technologies and industry trends will also be covered.

Experience: It was not a technical course but on the flip side, required a good understanding of business requirements as well as the current landscape of the Fintech environment to score well.  This is especially so for the group project which in my year involved building, researching and presenting a fintech idea.  The course itself provides a good overview of the tech needs of retail banks. If one were to join tech teams in non-retail banks, this course would be less relevant, but Prof's stories of his work experience should at the very least serve to give you insights into the industry.

Experience: Literally learn nothing from data mining if you already took machine learning and the exam is badly formatted with many errors in the questions. The lessons are also conducted in a very rush manner with the professor following the time given strictly. However, he is a new professor so i think it's due to the lack of experience.
Improvement: The professor need to slow down his pace of teaching and answer the students' queries
CourseDescription: Data mining consists of a wide range of data analysis techniques that can be applied to large datasets to discover patterns, trends and other forms of knowledge embedded in the data.  In the commercial world, data mining is often conducted on enterprise data stored in relational databases to help managers make informed decisions so as to keep businesses competitive and attuned to changing market conditions. With the recent advances in data generation and collection, new data types such as text, web, spatial, and temporal data have emerged creating new opportunities for mining knowledge from data for business intelligence.  This course provides an introduction to the fundamental issues and basic techniques of data mining.  The topics covered include data mining process, data preprocessing, data mining techniques and data mining evaluation.  In particular, the use of data mining in support to business intelligence and decision making will be covered through labs, projects and case studies.  Students are expected to learn data mining and its use in business intelligence through acquiring the basic data mining concepts and techniques, using them to explore data, and deriving useful knowledge patterns from the data through hands-on programming and experimentation that involve some industry strength data mining software packages.

Experience: This mod is pretty easy to understand and score. Really great way to learn Machine Learning and will be useful to take prior to Intro to ML mod. Prof is really nice, and project workload is manageable.
Improvement: More focus on coding aspect.

Experience: I felt that this is a more practical version of the Analytics Foundation module with the group project component added in. Some of the topics taught in Analytics Foundation is repeated so students who have taken that module would have an easier time. The workload is generally manageable with no finals as well.
Improvement: Remove group evaluation for the group project.
CourseDescription: Data mining consists of a wide range of data analysis techniques that can be applied to large datasets to discover patterns, trends and other forms of knowledge embedded in the data.  In the commercial world, data mining is often conducted on enterprise data stored in relational databases to help managers make informed decisions so as to keep businesses competitive and attuned to changing market conditions. With the recent advances in data generation and collection, new data types such as text, web, spatial, and temporal data have emerged creating new opportunities for mining knowledge from data for business intelligence.  This course provides an introduction to the fundamental issues and basic techniques of data mining.  The topics covered include data mining process, data preprocessing, data mining techniques and data mining evaluation.  In particular, the use of data mining in support to business intelligence and decision making will be covered through labs, projects and case studies.  Students are expected to learn data mining and its use in business intelligence through acquiring the basic data mining concepts and techniques, using them to explore data, and deriving useful knowledge patterns from the data through hands-on programming and experimentation that involve some industry strength data mining software packages.

Experience: A generally chill mod if you have previous analytics background. I would say compared to text mining and analytics foundation (mods I've taken) in terms of difficulty, it ranks somewhere in the middle. Finals is quite competitive and theory heavy (word-for-word answers from the slides), so a tip is that your finals cheatsheet should include stuff from the slides word-for-word.
CourseDescription: Data mining consists of a wide range of data analysis techniques that can be applied to large datasets to discover patterns, trends and other forms of knowledge embedded in the data.  In the commercial world, data mining is often conducted on enterprise data stored in relational databases to help managers make informed decisions so as to keep businesses competitive and attuned to changing market conditions. Experience: For my experience in AY22-23 Term 1, this module has a very steep learning curve, hence not a really manageable workload. Before recess week you'll have a fun time with Tableau but after recess week you'll have to start using D3, CSS and HTML. These are all required in assignments and weekly submissions so be prepared for it. The project is surprisingly manageable as my Prof (Prof Wang Yong) allows some freedom to explore what your group wants to do. Would not recommend this module unless you really want to try these programming languages without going through WAD1 and WAD2. I will, however, recommend this module to anyone who wants to compliment their business skills with technical and analytical ones.   Also the final quiz hits like a truck. Never take it lightly, so study the different visualizations and the visualization principles and the small calculations required (if any)
Improvement: Try having a head start in html, css and javascript and understand how they work ahead of time. Revise for the final quiz by going through the different visualizations and understanding them as they might overwhelm you with information overload if you study them too late.
CourseDescription: Data analysis and communications can be fun!  With visual analytics techniques and tools, everyday data analysts from various disciplines such business, economic, sociology, political science and public policy can now synthesize information and derive insight from massive, dynamic, ambiguous, and often conflicting data without having to deal with complex statistical formulas and programming.  Many companies and organization took notice when Gartner cited visual analytics as one of the top five trends transforming business intelligence.  In this course, students learn how to use data visualization and interactive analytic tools and techniques to interact with data of different formats from various sources, explore the expected relationships and discover unexpected correlations and patterns.

Experience: Beneficial module to learn about how analytics could be applied to social networks and social media, even though the project workload could be high, the main takeaway from this course is network analytics as well as scrapping from various social media platforms either using APIs or manually using tools such as selenium. Quiz is extremely important to do well in the module.
Improvement: Would be great if more emphasis could be put on the coding aspect of the network analytics instead of using 3rd party software to perform the analytics
CourseDescription: In today’s globally connected, online and mobile world, social media platforms are fast becoming the dominant means of communication and it is revolutionizing the way businesses communicate with their customers. Many popular social media platforms such as Facebook and Twitter allow for instant, real-time multi-way communication. Collecting and analysing data from multiple online sources require an Information Technology infrastructure. The data collected from online sources create a gold mine for businesses that want to understand and predict consumer and market behaviour. By leveraging sophisticated computing technologies, big data analytics can produce actionable insights valuable to the core operations of the business. This course will explore emerging methods and applications for understanding online user behaviour on popular social media platforms. Students will be exposed to a variety of real-world business cases, a collection of data analytics tools, best practices and hands-on exercises. Students will learn how to 1) identify analytics problems, 2) use data analytics tools and identify types of analysis to be performed, and 3) close the loop (the process of taking the analysis results and interpreting it contextually).

Experience: Work load is very heavy. Quiz focuses on tipping point book and in class ppt. Do study well as the quiz might be hard. Project scope can be huge depending on your topic. Ultimately, this is a SMU-X mod and do take it seriously as there are many learning points while you're doing your project, which makes your journey for this module meaningful.

Experience: The module is quite heavy in general. Bi-weekly quizzes, 2 individual assignments and 1 final SMU-X project. However, the module covers many useful and interesting technical aspects in Social Analytics using Python like Scrapping, Text Analysis, Sentiment Analysis and Network Analysis. Oh and subsidized AWS Certification at the end too. Worth the take!

Experience: Module teaches not only the technical aspect that consists of web scrapping & crawling, social network analysis, visualisation of textual data, sentiment analysis. But also the psychological side on about how humans interact in the pass

Experience: MUST take if you are looking to delve into SWE career. Highly recommended for any CS/IS/technical tech related students as this is the fundamental for programming.   However, things to note: heavy workload (but manageable)
Improvement: - Start project early (bid with a team that does work) - Make sure your project is in line with the sponsor's requirement
CourseDescription: This course focuses on fundamental concepts of developing programs using an object orientated approach. There will be an emphasis on writing clean and efficient code, and the ability to use an appropriate data structure or algorithm to solve problems. The Java programming language will be taught in depth. Students are expected to have a strong foundation in programming.  This is a compulsory course for IS (Software Development Track) for 2017 intake and onwards.  Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:  1. Practice problem solving skills  2. Read UML sequence and class diagrams 3. Apply basic concepts of Object Orientation to a given scenario/context  4. Apply good programming practices and design concepts to develop software 5. Appreciate the role of algorithms and in problem solving

Experience: My experience was amazing, I always look forward to his class as he gives small tidbits of wisdom / extra content which are not part of the syllabus but important to take note of if you wanna be a dev / use it in the project For project-wise, I would recommend using a framework like spring-boot, not because of the intention of trying to score well, but because of the joy of learning. Using it will introduce you to a lot more stuff not covered in the lessons like what is java beans, dependency injection, usage of repository patterns, dao, dto, multi-module, logging etc, which I find useful !   Also, I would recommend liaising with the client for the project and showing them like every 2 weeks on your progress, so that their mental model will be closer to your team project product  To sum up, this mod, makes me want to pursue dev as a career even more!
Improvement: Maybe can cover and touch some of the important gang of four design patterns? I think the philosophy from it would be beneficial for the students

However, you still have a lot of things to learn after class if you wanna be a JAVA developer. The external project is very interesting, which gives you a chance to apply all u learned. You can also self-learn some frameworks which are not covered in class and apply them in your project, which is a plus but not a must.
Improvement: N/A

The project was super fun, despite being stresful at first, and it really helps you apply not only what you've learned in class but also makes you explore things outside of the class.
Improvement: More engagement with the project sponsor as I felt there was not enough information stated on the project guidelines.

Experience: Especially useful if you are interested to understand how enterprise technology work at big companies (not just banks).   Lecture content is heavy and difficult to study (lots of framework and concepts). IMO.. the practical labs seem to be quite poorly made, old and not so useful..  Nonetheless still a NOT BAD module.. you also get the flexibility to do development or theory-based presentation as your project.
Improvement: Understand your project value well for the Q&A
CourseDescription: This course examines the role of Enterprise Architecture in implementing a bank’s business strategy while minimizing the overall IT cost for the bank.  In today’s market where the speed of doing business is rapidly increasing, and customers are becoming increasingly more sophisticated, banks are challenged to provide faster and better services, anytime, anywhere.  Technology, as a business enabler, has become a key consideration of any bank’s strategy.  An Enterprise Architecture aligns to the overall business strategy of the bank, and allows the bank to be agile, while minimizing IT costs through platform standardization.  The adoption of Enterprise Platforms such as Service-Oriented Architecture, Business Process Management, Business Rules Management Systems, and Complex Event Processing Engines will improve a bank’s competitive advantage with measurable results; increased revenue, speed to market, product & service innovation, improved agility, reduced cost.   Emphasis is placed throughout this course on analysing real-world situations using case studies, in particular large-scale change scenarios such as; core banking system replacements, and bank mergers whereby multiple vendor products need to coexist.  Hands-on lab exercises and project assignments will include the assembly of prototype banking solutions which invoke the API of SMU Teaching Bank (SMU tBank).

Experience: The module should have been renamed to IS452 Blockchain in Financial Applications. Workload is managable. Theory content might have to study beyond course content. Project group of 5 person. Coding requried
Improvement: Labs are outdated
CourseDescription: This course explores corporate banking and smart contracts. It begins by describing corporate customers and the financial services that they need. These considerations are then examined in different corporate business contexts. Specifically, the product areas of corporate lending, cash management & payments, trade finance, and corporate treasury are covered. The later part of the course covers smart contracts, an emerging technology to be used in corporate and institutional banking. Emphasis is placed throughout the course on analysing real-world situations using case studies and gaining hands-on experience with banking systems.

Experience: This mod is super fluff and 0% technical, even the profs are mostly sharing life stories during the whole lesson time haha (the profs are nice). 2 projects required us to make pitch videos as if you were pitching a product to a client. The projects were very manageable as well as long as you have members contributing equally. The only struggle I faced was clearing the superbadges. Good thing, no finals
CourseDescription: The better any organisation can manage the relationship with its customers, the more successful it will become. IT systems targeting the problems of dealing with customers are growing in popularity. Customer Relationship Management (CRM) is not just the use of a technology, or a hardcoded business process, it is a management strategy to help organisations understand and learn about customer behaviours, needs, preferences and expectations in order to improve and maintain a strong relationship with them.Managing Customer Relationship with Analytics: Asian Insights presents the concepts and methodologies required to execute a methodical approach to apply analytics and CRM principles into a business. The course will cover the customer-centric business culture, and the customer relationship process to attract, convert, retain and amaze customers with the help of IT tools.

Experience: This course was somewhat really useless. They revolved it around using Trailhead salesforce but do not touch on it in class. In class it was mostly just listening to lectures about sales and lead generation.
Improvement: Teach more of Salesforce and have hands on labs in class.

Experience: This was a weird mod, as I was in the first batch that this mod was released to the BA course.  It felt very shallow in terms of the technical work (analytics wise - mostly dashboarding), and rather the focus was more of the process of finding, engaging, closing, and re-engaging clients. Decent video editing skills is a must for this mod.
Improvement: More technical focus on the analytics portion.

Experience: Took this mod in AY2021/2022 Sem 2. And I can safely say... it was a HORRIBLE experience. Yeah workload was tbh okay as no midterms or quizzes, and projects and assignments (group work) were okay but I had terrible groupmates who didn't put in effort and it killed me (started on presentation slides 2 DAYS before presentation). So if you want to bid for this mod, be sure to bid with friends who you know can put in effort. Lecture-wise it was not bad to understand BUT the labs always gave me a headache, although they were not tested in finals. So tbh I didn't get the point of the labs at all as they were sooooo hard to understand. Overall, I think other BA mods more worth imo.
Improvement: just take out the labs pls I seriously didn't understand a single thing out of it
CourseDescription: Given the dominance of text information over the Internet, mining high-quality information from text becomes increasingly critical. The actionable knowledge extracted from text data facilitates our life in a broad spectrum of areas, including business intelligence, information acquisition, behavior analysis and decision making process. In this course, we will cover important topics in ext mining including: document representation, text categorization and clustering, sentiment analysis, probabilistic topic models and text visualization. Text mining techniques adopt the models from research areas such as Statistics, NLP and Linguistics. We will also focus on basic natural language processing techniques, language parsing and analysis and evaluation techniques.

Experience: Fantastic. It covers basic NLP techniques from preprocessing methods, such as lemmatization and stopword removal, to applications, such as named entity recognition and sentiment analysis. We also get hands on practice every class, and the project really reinforces your learnings. Highly recommended if you intend to venture into NLP related fields.

We will also focus on basic natural language processing techniques, language parsing and analysis and evaluation techniques.

Experience: Blended learning module, means you have to watch the online lecture before class. But the content for each week is manageable. Just have to focus on the lab portion because that is where it takes up most of your time trying to understand the purpose of the code/ analysis
Improvement: Lecture/ content wise is easy to understand once you understand the lab .
CourseDescription: Financial analytics is to identify insights from vast amount of data that most of the financial institutions have to help them to answer specific business questions and to forecast possible future financial scenarios.  Banks are investing a lot of money on the use of data analytics in their daily business processes from customer acquisition, targeting the customers to cross-sell and up-selling and fraud detection.  With such massive amounts of data collected and huge potential value that are found in these data for marketing, risk management and business process improvement; thus, the demand for analytics professionals to make sense of these data is also increasing.The skills and knowledge that are needed for analytics professional in the banks would require a wide array of skills such as data management, analysis, mathematics & statistics, business and not forgetting intimate knowledge of the financial services domain, especially regulations and compliance.The module aims to bring these skills and knowledge together, to bridge the gap between analytics techniques and their applications in financial institutions. Using current applications of analytics in financial institution, coupled with class discussion, labs and guest speakers from the industry, the students can understand how domain knowledge (such as banking objectives and regulations) interacts with the other areas of the analytics value chain.This module is also designed to take advantage of the diversity in students’ background to give varied points-of-view during each lab projects and discussion. This closely emulates many bank’s analytics environment. To ensure students have the required level of knowledge and skills, pre-requisites are set.After the module, students would be able to identify potential areas with consideration on the current banking landscape shaped by regional and local regulators, being able to state down the challenges in the implementation, allowing them to propose valuable analytics solutions that are actionable by the financial institutions. This will give them an edge in their financial services analytics career.

Experience: Took the course taught by Prof Kyong. Will learn more on AWS services related to Big Data (Glue, Athena, QuickSight, etc.) and a bit on theories regarding Big Data. To complete the group project, it is expected to study the technologies on our own, Prof provides some basic exercises for us to setup and do basic things. The quizzes are easy as the things tested are just pure memory, but because of this the things tested are not your understanding of Big Data but on how well you memorize the content. Can create cheatsheet though. Overall the course itself is not too technical, depends whether you prefer this kind of mod or otherwise.
Improvement: Learn the tech stack that Prof explains on your own free time. It will be better if you are familiar in using AWS. For quizzes and exams, memorize everything in the content that Prof gives with more focus on the videos and articles that Prof provides.
CourseDescription: Data Architecture is a vast area of expertise covering multiple types of data usage. Data Architecture applies to Operational use cases, Decision making processes as well as Analytical use cases. With the advent of Data Warehouses, Data Marts and Data Lakes, Data Architecture has become an important and imminent process in the Data Analytics and Business Intelligence world. The success of a Data Analytics and Business Intelligence initiative depends heavily on the Data Architecture put in place. At the same time Data Architecture can also be ambiguous, subjective and open to interpretations, depending on circumstances. This course will provide a “Guided path to Data Architecture, in the field of BIG DATA”. That means, this course will address the architectural needs of Data Analytics and Business Intelligence. It will provide a prescriptive, unambiguous and objective methodology to arrive at the Data Architecture for any business/entity that wishes to perform Data Analytics or indulge in Business Intelligence. Students are expected to learn how to methodically, step by step derive Data Architecture. This will be a practical course with heavy emphasis on project work involving hands-on architectural work. The course will involve a lot of group discussions, scenario analysis and mini-workshops.

Experience: The course runs through some fundamental machine learning techniques and models and it's helpful if you want to get a start on knowing what exactly ML is. It is quite lacking in terms of application; the only hands-on experience you'll get are in the 15-20min long lab demos at the end of each class and the project. There is simple math (calculus and matrix multiplication) involved. Overall not a very tough mod, workload is light (2 assignments) and Prof is very fair on grading.
Improvement: The questions in assignments/exams are just repurposed versions of the examples in the slides, so practice those.
CourseDescription: Machine Learning is one of the fundamental subjects in the field of Artificial Intelligence. Machine Learning is concerned with computer programs that automatically improve their performance through experience (e.g., learning to recognize images or speech, classifying text documents, detecting credit card frauds, or driving autonomous vehicles).  This course covers both fundamental theory, practical algorithms and the applications for machine learning from a variety of perspectives. It includes a range of topics, from supervised learning (such as Naïve Bayes Classifier, Linear Regression, Logistic Regression, and Neural Networks) and their applications, to unsupervised learning (such as Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and Singular Value Decomposition (SVD)) and their applications, and from traditional (shallow) learning (such as Support Vector Machine (SVM)) to recent state-of-the-art deep learning methods (such as Recurrent Neural Networks (RNN) and Convolutional Neural Network (CNN)). The course is intended to prepare students for basic understanding of machine learning fundamentals and equip students with the capability to apply machine learning techniques through real world business applications (to solve real world problems).NOTE: This is an algorithm and technical course, and it is highly recommended that students are proficient in programming, probabilities, statistics, linear algebra and calculus. Solid math background will be very useful and helpful for your learning journey. It is highly recommended that students have taken IS424 Data Mining and Business Analytics first if you do not have such math background knowledge. Having taken IS424 first will make this difficult course, Machine Learning & Applications, easier.

Experience: Was a great experience getting to work with a real industry, developing products for them and experiencing the software development lifecycle. Grading can be a little unfair as it is determined by the professors and not the company itself.
Improvement: Allow companies to grade the projects
CourseDescription: TBC

Experience: Prof Kan Siew Ning is one of the most chill prof I've ever experienced learning under. He's down-to-earth, knowledgeable in the topics he teaches and welcomes students to ask questions. He's very generous with class participation and does in fact calls the class up when there is a class part opportunity. The module itself is not technical heavy and is very friendly for most people who is interested in learning about managing sustainable smart cities. Projects were manageable and in fact really fun to explore new horizons in terms of research and innovation.  One thing I do have to precaution others considering his class is that he does expect students to revise terminologies that were taught or told to look up (in the first lesson one of his self-reflection questions is learning how a phone works). It can be very broad sometimes so students have to really be open with learning new things via self-research. It's not that its a bad thing but when the final quiz comes up it encapsulates basically EVERYTHING he has went through (from healthcare to roads to even waste management). Grading itself may differ from time to time but so far he's an understandable prof who does not slack in terms of reasonable standards.
Improvement: Engage with the prof if you have questions, even if it might tangent off from what he's currently teaching. Curiosity is the only limit. Just don't forget to learn what he actually puts in the slides haha.
CourseDescription: This course will equip students with core knowledge of appreciating what it takes to plan, design, build and sustain digital (‘smart’) cities that are innovative, inclusive, safe, resilient and sustainable. By the end of this course, students will be able to appreciate the following 4 areas: Urban Challenges, Urban Sustainability, Design of ‘Smart’ Digital Cities and Commercialisation of selected digital city projects. There will be an introduction to how software can be used to provide solutions for smart city challenges.

Experience: Note: I took his class fully online under Prof Kan Siew Ning so things might differ from physical lessons/other professors.  Had a good time in this module learning about sustainability, green projects and the importance of moving towards such solutions in the future.   The module is not very technical. More of project management mixed with some technical knowledge (if you have little to none, don't worry. Some Google searches and reading up and you should be alright!). Workload was manageable imo: 2 projects (1 due each half of the term) worth 40% total, a 25% 1500-1800 words term paper (due around week 8) and a 25% multi-select MCQ online quiz in week 13.   With good team members, diligence and effort, you should be able to score decently for the group projects (which are based on the bell curve). Try to really explore the topic given to you, be innovative and try your best to deliver relevant content.   As for term paper, he gives a range of topics to stay within and you can derive your own. Be sure to read the rubrics and start the term paper early as it's due in recess week.   The were 25 questions for the online quiz I did. They were tricky and tested his slides' contents (which can be quite a lot as he covers many topics, albeit not in depth) as well as points mentioned in class (so take notes in class!). I suggest, if you want to score well, try to read up on slides before class, pay attention during class and after class, just do a quick scan through of the slides and your notes again so that you understand and can better retain the information.   Class participation was worth 10%, which was manageable, as he gives opportunities each class (even if the content is dry, he really tries to ask the class questions. He's very willing to let students get their class participation!). He also notes down names of students and will try to pick those who have not spoken in class over those who have spoken a few times already - he's fair in that sense, which is great. And his questions are not the super challenging or technical type, it's more of really getting the class to participate and interact so that we can learn from one another.  Bid for SMT112!
Improvement: NIL

Experience: A content module that helps me understand more about cities, sustainability, and how technology can help to make cities smarter. The projects are very interesting and hands-on, because you get to work on a novel idea in project management style. There are also field trips, so it is quite fun!
Improvement: The structure of the module is not very clear, but I heard the professor improves it every semester.

Experience: Introductory programming course with C language. Might be a bit of a learning curve for people with no programming background. Though there are plenty of exercises to practice. The lecturers are all very nice and will definitely help you if you are struggling. The same goes for the TA. Just don't be shy and ask them questions. It'll payoff in the long run.
Improvement: Do not solely rely on the classes to help you as they tend to go quickly. Make sure to spend some time outside of class doing extra practices or to clarify on why certain problems are done a certain way.
CourseDescription: This course introduces students to computational concepts and basic programming.  Students will learn the basic programming constructs, and programming techniques to solve problem. An imperative language called C is used as the vehicle of exploration. There is an emphasis on producing clear, robust, and reasonably efficient code using top-down design, and effective testing and debugging.

Experience: Very interesting, professor made the lesson enjoyable and easy to understand. Great foundation for future CS courses :) Though pointers may be a tough concept to learn in the beginning, the prof's visual representations helped greatly in understanding the course.
Improvement: study lol
CourseDescription: This course introduces students to computational concepts and basic programming.  Students will learn the basic programming constructs, and programming techniques to solve problem. An imperative language called C is used as the vehicle of exploration. There is an emphasis on producing clear, robust, and reasonably efficient code using top-down design, and effective testing and debugging.

Experience: Prof was very experienced and had a perfect balance of workload. Skills taught are key to starting to code, and the exercises are written with care. Given the structure of the exams (70% of the questions are almost impossible to get wrong, and the other 30% is almost impossible to get correct), it is extremely easy to get a B+ and below but to get an A, you will probably have to put in a very very significant amount of effort after class, even with prior coding experience.
Improvement: Perhaps change the language from C to something more applicable in the modern world.

An imperative language called C is used as the vehicle of exploration. There is an emphasis on producing clear, robust, and reasonably efficient code using top-down design, and effective testing and debugging.

Experience: Took this when I was a freshie in 2019. Overall the workload was all right, but the weekly quizzes take into account your retainment of knowledge after every lesson, so you'll have to keep on your toes.
Improvement: nil

An imperative language called C is used as the vehicle of exploration. Experience: Simple mod to start off a CS journey. Expect to do a lot of practice if you are not familiar with coding before entering university. Homework is mostly easy but attempting the most difficult questions will really prepare you for your exams.
Improvement: The exams tend to be either disproportionately easy or difficult. A better balance will do but it's unlikely

Experience: This mod teaches C language in my year. I heard that C may not be the best language to start learning if you are new to programming but the opinions vary. I'm not sure if you should take this mod if you are a complete beginner, but I do know that if you are taking this mod, it is better to have some programming background (in any langs, no matter how much you learnt) before you enter. I learnt Python for a month before entering and it helped a lot in the first few weeks because there are weekly quizzes (at least for my prof), so it would be better to have experience and secure the scores for the first few quizzes.

Experience: The course was alright, but the content was difficult. The teaching was sub-par and I could say that many of us had to watch YouTube lectures in order to better grasp the content. However, the professor is patient and willing to take his time to repeat his points.
Improvement: The teaching pace and tutorials could be better.
CourseDescription: This is an introductory course in Linear Algebra. It teaches the mathematical foundations of Linear Algebra so as to illustrate their relevance to computer science and applications. It prepares the students for advanced numeric methods in computing, especially in machine learning and data analytics.

Experience: I think this is one of the harder mods for comp sci students in Y1S1. It is quite difficult to get everything taught even during finals. Our final paper is quite decent, but that's after some killer quizzes and mid-term (I'm guessing that they probably made the finals easier for us after the initial tough tests, but I'm not sure about future batches - maybe they will average out the difficulty levels across all the tests for yall).   Anyway, I would say not to worry about getting excellent grades for this mod because if you put in the necessary effort (tho prob more than other mods), getting an A- should still be achievable. It is an important mod especially for comp science students too. You can watch Gilbert Strang's videos on YouTube if you don't get anything too lol.
CourseDescription: This is an introductory course in Linear Algebra. It teaches the mathematical foundations of Linear Algebra so as to illustrate their relevance to computer science and applications. It prepares the students for advanced numeric methods in computing, especially in machine learning and data analytics.

Experience: This module was the hardest semester 1 module, mainly because you are likely not used to doing math that doesn't have a fixed set of equations to follow. Lots of proving, practice and this module will be a tough one. Despite being very difficult, the moderation ensures you a B even if it seems like you are gonna fail, so don't worry and just try your best!
Improvement: NIL
CourseDescription: This course serves as an introduction to the theory of discrete mathematics, which lays the foundation for computer science courses such as data structures, algorithms, relational database theory and cryptography. The topics covered in this course are mathematical logic, elementary number theory, recursion, set theory, functions, combinatorics and graphs. The course will consist of lectures and tutorials to help students understand the covered topics.

Experience: It is called 'Mathematical foundations' yet contains little to no numbers. Of course it varies from student to student, but I struggled with this mod as i found it really difficult to understand. However, with enough practice it becomes manageable. Still an important mod however!
Improvement: Not much, but more exposure to different question types would be nice.
CourseDescription: This course serves as an introduction to the theory of discrete mathematics, which lays the foundation for computer science courses such as data structures, algorithms, relational database theory and cryptography. The topics covered in this course are mathematical logic, elementary number theory, recursion, set theory, functions, combinatorics and graphs. The course will consist of lectures and tutorials to help students understand the covered topics.

Experience: Just like the name of the mod suggests, this mod is very math intensive. It takes some practice to be good at it but if your prof gives you enough practice, you should be good to go. There is quite a lot of practices available out there (i.e. textbooks).

The topics covered in this course are mathematical logic, elementary number theory, recursion, set theory, functions, combinatorics and graphs. Experience: This is a really interesting, and the most important course for tech based roles. It exposes you to actual mathematical concepts used in computer science. Prof Hady teaches really well. There is heavy workload and weekly assessments.
Improvement: Lesser amount of workload and/or make it SMUX
CourseDescription: This course builds on students’ earlier programming experiences, moving beyond syntax and logic, to the question of how to build “better” programs focusing on organizing data and designing algorithms for efficiency.  The materials as well as the assignments rely heavily on proficiency with Java programming language.Students will learn:•	the concept of efficiency, why it is important for programs to be efficient and scalable, how to manage the trade-offs of computational time as well as resources such as memory, and how to compare the efficiency of various algorithms,•	problem-solving through judicious organization of data, how abstract data types allow encapsulation and localization, as well as how their concrete implementations in the form of various data structures allow for efficient access and modification of data,•	algorithmic strategies such as divide-and-conquer, iteration, recursion, randomization, etc., to achieve more effective problem solving and more efficient solutions.This course is different from Computational Thinking, as it goes into the theoretical underpinnings of efficiency, covers more data structures, and delves deeply into the implementations of those data structures.

Experience: I felt that the module was pretty interesting as we learnt about the basic data structures used in CS. Introductory course so we learnt more about breadth than depth. Thought the project was quite heavy for only a small weightage though.
Improvement: Lessen the project workload or increase the weightage of the project.

Experience: Erm, do it. And if you are a CS major, you have to do it anyways.

Experience: super good module to pick software engineering skills (frontend/backend), but the project is super heavy if you do not have any experience and its only 35%? i feel like the effort is not so worth, because in the end the exam and quizes matter more.
Improvement: increase the weightage of the project so that its more worth the effort.
CourseDescription: This course exposes students to web and micro services development, software design issues, agile processes and project management techniques. The focus is to allow students to experience agile software development and project management by working in a team to develop a web based application.

Experience: This module does teach many interesting and useful skills (Git, Agile Methodologies, Springboot) that we will need for future modules & in the workplace.  However, the workload is insane, and the project is very tough. You'll really need very good groupmates, because the project can really tank your final grade!
Improvement: 1. The project could be made simpler, there's just too many requirements 2. This is supposedly an smu-x module, but we barely even got to work with the sponsor, except for a few meetings to show your progress. Didn't get any meaningful feedback from the sponsor, nor experience working with a real sponsor.
CourseDescription: This course exposes students to web and micro services development, software design issues, agile processes and project management techniques. Experience: This module was pretty interesting. It was an SMU-X module so the project was quite a big one. However, the project was quite interesting and taught basic but good coding habit and important techniques when working in a team.

This course teaches about the basics of software development -- Git and version control, Spring, Springboot, code refactoring, pair programming. Although difficult, you will learn a lot from this course if you are a beginner.

Experience: Heavy theory content but the project is hell, it's fun though if you know what you're doing, if you don't well you're going to learn a lot from this project's module especially since it's a SMU-X mod. Don't be shy to consult prof or TA since the project is not exactly what the mod is teaching since it's mostly theory.

Experience: The course is theory based and not very heavy. Concepts are really interesting and very well explained. The workload is very manageable. Make sure to study regularly for this course and be interactive in class discussions as they are very useful
Improvement: More exercises can be done
CourseDescription: This course prepares students to design, deploy, and manage the interconnection of networking devices, including cyber-physical systems. It covers fundamental computer communication concepts, including switching, signalling, encoding and transmission, modern network technology, protocols (TCP, UDP, IP), and wireless (cellular and wireless LAN). Besides helping students to understand the key technologies conceptually, the course is structured to develop students’ skills in building, analyzing, and evaluation simple communication networks.

Experience: Highly recommend for CS and IS students since this course teaches basic network and security knowledge which is fundamental for any CS/IS students.

It covers fundamental computer communication concepts, including switching, signalling, encoding and transmission, modern network technology, protocols (TCP, UDP, IP), and wireless (cellular and wireless LAN). Besides helping students to understand the key technologies conceptually, the course is structured to develop students’ skills in building, analyzing, and evaluation simple communication networks.

Experience: The module is quite theoretical, but he made it simple to understand. Not much coding in this module unless you choose a project that requires you to code.  Otherwise, there is none.  Project scope is super broad so you can choose to do anything you want

Besides helping students to understand the key technologies conceptually, the course is structured to develop students’ skills in building, analyzing, and evaluation simple communication networks.

Experience: it makes me question myself why did I take this module in the first place. Don't recommend to take as this module is really hard to understand,
CourseDescription: A key challenge in many AI systems is being able to handle (reason, plan or learn) problems with uncertainty. For instance, a self-driving car needs to handle imperfect visibility of the world and also uncertainty about the movements of other cars or obstacles. Similarly, in aggregation systems (e.g., Grab, Food Panda), positioning supply (taxis, delivery boys) at the right locations requires handling uncertainty about customer demand. Playing strategic games like Go, Chess etc. requires learning strategy that works against opponents whose strategy is not known in advance.  This course will equip students with core concepts and practical experience in doing reasoning, learning and planning in the presence of uncertainty.

Experience: Prof is able to explain the content quite well, the content is well structured, assignments are very doable, and no exams. Group project is quite doable, but the grade I guess depends on how well your group performed compared to the other groups. Prof is nice, he is approachable during and after class. Although need to be careful in following his instructions, as he will immediately cut scores if you did not follow his instructions.
Improvement: Read the slides like a bible, it would help you a lot during quizzes which is a determining factor in acing the course. Doing well on assignments is very doable and Prof gave us a lot of time to prepare (1 month for each assignment).
CourseDescription: Natural Language Communication (NLC) is the convergence of a diverse set of human language technologies that enable computer systems to interact reasonably with people in a natural and human-like way. NLC requires considering human language as the central part of communicative channel, where the computer should be able to perform a series of language processing actions: 1) It should correctly process our written or spoken utterances as input in order to respond accordingly; 2) It should allow technology to understand complex sentences, which may contain multiple pieces of information and many turns of requests; 3) It can then react by reasoning and/or interrogating and synthesizing various data from third-party systems or external knowledge, and use that information in generating sensible responses. In this course, we will cover diverse fundamental methods and techniques across the themes of natural language processing, understanding and generation that are indispensable for constructing modern NLC systems. We will be focused on introducing and discussing the underlying computational models, data resources, toolkits, and practicing them in developing interactive information seeking, dialogue, and cross-language communication systems. This includes but is not limited to exploration of a few conversational AI applications such as question answering, chatbots, virtual personal assistants, and automatic translation for spontaneous dialogues.

Experience: Good if you are interested in chatbot, else take other AI electives to clear your requirement.

Experience: Mod is very dry, have to study really hard to understand. As this is a very new mod, please voice your concerns to her. She is very nice. In fact, you can learn more about management in Cyber Security for different entities. If you're pursuing an IT career, you can understand more from this module.
CourseDescription: Information security is not just a technical issue but a critical policy and business issue. The purpose of this course is to help students acquire the knowledge and build up the capability to understand and analyse the key policy and business issues pertaining to information security threats and countermeasures, based on a solid understanding of cyber security ecosystem along with the dynamics of technology innovation and in the context of digital transformation.  We approach this purpose by integrating four learning components, including technical countermeasures designed to protect information systems, economics theories as the foundation of information security policy, case studies and getting-into data throughout the teaching process.  It is recommended that students have the capability to use at least one of the data processing and analytics tools, e.g., Excel. Students should have basic knowledge about computer system, software and networking.

Experience: The first thing I have to say is the cost! You have to pay to view the case studies, pay to play the game, pay to even view your final case study... I took IS110 under ma dan and the content is quite dry but props to her to try to make the class engaging with group activities and active discussion in class. She would also try to give those who have not spoken a chance but mostly it will be the usual few class parting.  The information to do for case study project is not quite sufficient and no comments were made on it after presentation.  Quite a fluff mod with not much workload except for the group work, so you will have lots of free time in the first 10 weeks or so and chiong the last few weeks for the project and final exam. Final exam is also quite manageable.
Improvement: Listen to any starred parts from the guest presenter and try to analyse the final case study with groupmates and search for potential questions.
CourseDescription: In this course, you will get an overview of fundamental business concepts with an emphasis on the challenges and opportunities that arise from technology and how information systems can be used to create business value and innovations.

Experience: Theory learnt from the module is not as much as when being compared with other modules. A case study will be assigned weekly for the learning purposes. More time is needed for presentation component in my opinion. Quizzes are manageable but a few questions are slightly challenging. Class participation is doable if you understand the case study assigned. Final exam will be the main component to determine your grade and it is set to be challenging. Don's be surprised if your grade might drop a little.
Improvement: Listen carefully in class and try to participate in the class discussion.
CourseDescription: In this course, you will get an overview of fundamental business concepts with an emphasis on the challenges and opportunities that arise from technology and how information systems can be used to create business value and innovations.

Experience: Generally as others said, very smoke module. Very difficult to control your grade in the quizzes (especially multi-select where it is all or nothing), and also for the project, which is case facilitation. Workload is generally light, and grades-wise it is difficult to do too well or too badly (apparently B is normal).
Improvement: Under the prof I am taking, case facilitation expectations should be made clear. It is really unclear what he wants even after I see the rubric.
CourseDescription: In this course, you will get an overview of fundamental business concepts with an emphasis on the challenges and opportunities that arise from technology and how information systems can be used to create business value and innovations.

Experience: Honestly this mod is very fluff because of the way this mod is structured. Other than that, I believe that this mod is actually very interesting to take for an information systems student studying here in SMU. Ultimately, we come here to gain insights on how IT can integrate into businesses, and that's what this mod does. With the help of case studies based on historical examples, we learn how previous companies have both succeeded and failed with their IT systems, and learn more about their business models as well. We didn't come to take IS solely for CS nor solely for business, so I believe this mod is honestly very interesting despite the bad reviews by others!
Improvement: NIL
CourseDescription: In this course, you will get an overview of fundamental business concepts with an emphasis on the challenges and opportunities that arise from technology and how information systems can be used to create business value and innovations.

Experience: rather fluff mod, the workload is okay. don't really learn much either because the prof throws you into the facilitation without any clarification on the topic and the explanation after is quite brief. class part is crazy hard, people queuing up just to answer questions that haven't been asked. under prof hoe and hes just focusing on defending himself and his teaching (which isn't great), he also makes the class feel bad to steer the class towards the way he wants, the literal definition of gaslight. group mates are preassigned and I must say I drew the short end of the stick.... bad mod in general just don't bother.

Experience: Expected this module to be more technical and teach stuff about platforms like SAS....turns out it's more of a business module, so be prepared for that.   Personally I don't quite understand this module. From week 3 till the second last academic week, each group will facilitate a case about real-life business-related IT for the first half of the class, followed by a lecture from the prof for the second half. 70% of the time, I felt like I was paying school fees to be taught (can we even say that if it's other tuition fee-paying people who are teaching me???) by my own peers than the professor lol   Final exam was pretty doable, it's an open-book exam. Be sure to read the case multiple times and you should be good to go.   Honestly, didn't really enjoy this module and was dozing off half the time but it was a core module for me so ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

CourseDescription: In this course, you will get an overview of fundamental business concepts with an emphasis on the challenges and opportunities that arise from technology and how information systems can be used to create business value and innovations.

Experience: IS110 has a lot of reading to do. Do highlight and make notes of each case readings you have every week. It is what will help you to class part and contribute in the discussion. It seems more like a business mod relating to IT rather than just a purely technical mod.   During your group's facilitation, do manage the time and the question posted by your classmates well. Try not to overrun, it will affect your group's grades. Also, make sure to practice and time yourselves. Ask the questions you planned on asking your class with your teammates and friends to gather feedback if the question was unclear to it is alright.   Summary after each case is really helpful to understand the case. It is also a skill to pick up since before exam you will be given a case. Knowing which point to pay attention or take notes would be helpful to you during exam when you are stressed and have limited time.

CourseDescription: In practice, a management decision to invest in business process modeling is often motivated by the need to document requirements for an information technology project. So this course aims to help students: - Understand and apply BPM  project needs and life-cycle stages - Gain knowledge of business process and its role in an industry. - Understand business models and create models for the as-is business process. - Understand analysis techniques static and dynamic and  analyse the business process - Apply dynamic analysis techniques using tools and analyse the simulation results - Identify business needs in the process and convert them to the IT needs - Understand techniques for solutioning and design solution models for the to-be process - Understand enterprises and they are implemented in an organization. - Gain understanding of the process innovation and identify the needs for process innovation. - Analyze and review innovated business processes in industry cases where digital transformation is applied.

Experience: Learnt a lot of different skills that can be applied to the working world. The projects is really interesting as it asked us to analyse the existing company and asking us to come out with different solutions to help improve the business process.
Improvement: Maybe more time for the exams

Improvement: Remove the course completely.

I would say the content doesnt really value add to your learning, most of it are inherent knowledge anyway.

CourseDescription: In practice, a management decision to invest in business process modeling is often motivated by the need to document requirements for an information technology project. So this course aims to help students: - Understand and apply BPM  project needs and life-cycle stages - Gain knowledge of business process and its role in an industry. - Understand business models and create models for the as-is business process. - Understand analysis techniques static and dynamic and  analyse the business process - Apply dynamic analysis techniques using tools and analyse the simulation results - Identify business needs in the process and convert them to the IT needs - Understand techniques for solutioning and design solution models for the to-be process - Understand enterprises and they are implemented in an organization. - Gain understanding of the process innovation and identify the needs for process innovation. - Analyze and review innovated business processes in industry cases where digital transformation is applied.

Experience: The term-long group project enables students to put design thinking skills to practice. These skills may serve you well in the future.  In my opinion, there was too much to do for the project work. Final test weightage was also too much. The prof also needs to improve his English as some questions in the final test had grammatical errors and were ambiguous in meaning.
Improvement: Learning and memorizing the concepts taught in class are just as important as the project work. These concepts will be tested during the final test, which will weigh on the overall heavier than you'd expect.  Starting the group project early and making progress every week is very important due to time constraints.
CourseDescription: This course introduces fundamental human-computer interaction principles and techniques for designing usable interactive systems. Topics include common methods for gathering user requirements, basic UI and graphics programming techniques, and common evaluation techniques. Hands-on experience with UI prototyping tools will be provided and students will complete a UI design and prototyping project as part of this course.

Experience: Milestones to reach every week, good if your group can stay on track and meet deadlines. Otherwise, it could be tough to catch up because the work will pile up. Ideas generation is tough but important because the problem statement will be the basis on which every other task is built.
Improvement: nil
CourseDescription: This course introduces fundamental human-computer interaction principles and techniques for designing usable interactive systems. Topics include common methods for gathering user requirements, basic UI and graphics programming techniques, and common evaluation techniques. Hands-on experience with UI prototyping tools will be provided and students will complete a UI design and prototyping project as part of this course.

Experience: I'm going to be blunt here:  The setting of exams was abysmal with absolutely no QC. There are 4 instructors teaching this module, and all of them get to set their own questions for the exams. For example, in the exam there are 40 questions, there are 10 questions roughly from each prof. However, when looking at their slides on e-learn, all profs teach very different things. This means that students are only able to answer questions set by their prof, and the rest is up to guesswork. MOST if not all of the questions are vague and extremely subjective.  The grammar for half the questions is wrong and riddled with spelling mistakes and errors, which leaves me to wonder, who is responsible for vetting the content of the course exams?   The course flow (UI/UX design) is completely out of sync, and the order in which content is taught does not make any sense, it is just jumping around different topics with no logical flow. Most of the slides are outdated (at least 10 years old), and course content is mediocre at best, with irrelevant topics and terms thrown around. Project work was (shockingly) even worse than the exams themselves. Project load was ridiculous, and we spent a good 20-30 hours a week on this course alone.   The Prof and Instructor did not grade according to the rubrics, and I don't know how this went unnoticed, but there is absolutely no preparation between instructors. They are unaware of the main course outline in general and when asked questions often struggle to answer or provide incorrect clarification.
Improvement: - Please put more effort into writing the exams.  - The MCQ options are written so vaguely and poorly that answering them is more guesswork than actual logic. I cannot emphasise this enough. You can spend weeks studying and luck will determine whether you get an A or C - Update the slide contents. They seem like they were written a decade ago - Make the project more manageable, give a clearer outline, and spend more time explaining the deliverables.  - A 10 minute slipshod project requirements briefing after each lesson, given that 5-10 hours each week are spent on the project is unacceptable.
CourseDescription: This course introduces fundamental human-computer interaction principles and techniques for designing usable interactive systems. Topics include common methods for gathering user requirements, basic UI and graphics programming techniques, and common evaluation techniques. Hands-on experience with UI prototyping tools will be provided and students will complete a UI design and prototyping project as part of this course.

Experience: IDP was a fun module! Good module if you want to learn basic design pattern concepts. Manageable Workload. Light content. Project are good for you to apply the content you learned during the semester...
Improvement: n/a
