CourseDescription: This course introduces fundamental human-computer interaction principles and techniques for designing usable interactive systems. Topics include common methods for gathering user requirements, basic UI and graphics programming techniques, and common evaluation techniques. Hands-on experience with UI prototyping tools will be provided and students will complete a UI design and prototyping project as part of this course.

Experience: Interesting mod, a little bit of everything that you have to learn. The mid-terms can be slightly trick and subjective and it's a little hard to score well for subsequent exams especially cause we don't get good feedbacks from mid-terms.
Improvement: Maybe update the course syllabus and slides
CourseDescription: This course introduces fundamental human-computer interaction principles and techniques for designing usable interactive systems. Topics include common methods for gathering user requirements, basic UI and graphics programming techniques, and common evaluation techniques. Hands-on experience with UI prototyping tools will be provided and students will complete a UI design and prototyping project as part of this course.

Experience: IDP is quite different from your regular IS mod- it tries to quantify and grade 'look and feel' aspects of programming, and is really more of a design course than a programming one (zero code mod btw). If you're the very technical type with not-so-great human-touch instincts, you might flounder a little here, so get some artsy fartsy teammates to help with the project.   This mod is also perhaps the first to suggest that the IS career path is more than just SWE/Cybersec/Data Analyst; if you're the kind that struggles with programming in general and are wondering if IS was the right choice for you, this mod and the possibilities it offers will probably give you more options for roles in the tech space.  Workload is report and presentation heavy. Content is nothing to sniff at either.
Improvement: Curriculum feels a little unstructured in the sense that the different chapters taught never quite synergised together.
CourseDescription: This course introduces fundamental human-computer interaction principles and techniques for designing usable interactive systems. Topics include common methods for gathering user requirements, basic UI and graphics programming techniques, and common evaluation techniques. Hands-on experience with UI prototyping tools will be provided and students will complete a UI design and prototyping project as part of this course.

Experience: IDP was fun and exciting as it helps you to think out of the box especially when comes to real life problems people face. As for workload, indeed it is on the heavier side as there are alot of milestones to meet. Overall, I had fun taking this module.
Improvement: NIL

CourseDescription: This course introduces fundamental human-computer interaction principles and techniques for designing usable interactive systems. Topics include common methods for gathering user requirements, basic UI and graphics programming techniques, and common evaluation techniques. Hands-on experience with UI prototyping tools will be provided and students will complete a UI design and prototyping project as part of this course.

Experience: Very lightweight module because of COVID-19 (remote learning). You learn real-life software development processes such as Agile and Scrum. Very realistic course, unlike your typical theory bullshit.
CourseDescription: This course is geared to teach students project and people management skills in the context of a software project. This is done in a very hands-on manner where students are formed into teams and given a semester long project on day 1. This project will require them to work together to build a fully working web application prototype, that is deployed on a commercial cloud service, from scratch in a team of 5.

Experience: just ask anyone who's taken spm before theyll tell you it's the bane of their existence. faculty planning of the module is really screwed up and underprepared
CourseDescription: This course is geared to teach students project and people management skills in the context of a software project. This is done in a very hands-on manner where students are formed into teams and given a semester long project on day 1. This project will require them to work together to build a fully working web application prototype, that is deployed on a commercial cloud service, from scratch in a team of 5.

Experience: Workload is very heavy, could easily be like a 1.5CU mod. But groups are usually segmented so there're a mixture of students with different capabilities so it's less challenging to do the project. Presentations every 2 weeks which can be pretty scary and nerve-wrecking but no choice it also helps to simulate real world client review.

Experience: Great mod that teaches web development. Very useful skills learn and had a lot of fun doing it. Practical stuff too like the JS can be used for Soft Dev in the future if that is something that you want to explore
Improvement: Nothing
CourseDescription: This course is designed to equip students with knowledge and skills to develop well-styled and responsive web applications that provide rich user experiences. Combining with the skills learnt in IS113 course, which focuses on developing database-driven web applications with basic web designs, after this course, the students will be equipped with full stack web development skills, who can build both front-end and back-end software.   In the introductory weeks of the course, the students will revisit HTML and server-side programming (PHP) concepts learnt in IS113. Then, the students will learn the concept of “Styling” the web pages. The students will learn a style sheet language called cascading style sheets (CSS) and learn how to separate the content and presentation of web pages, how to control web page layout, colors and fonts, how to bring multiple styles into a web page, how to control the layout of multiple web pages efficiently, etc. Next, the students will learn the concept of adding responsive behaviors to web pages to enhance the user experience. The students will learn a client-side programming language called JavaScript to make ordinary web elements like input boxes, buttons, forms, tables, menus interactive and animated. Furthermore, they will learn how to connect to API gateways and process data from external sources like RESTful web services so that they can build practical applications. In the latter weeks of the course, the students will be introduced to programming with frameworks. The students will learn how to use frameworks to build complex web applications in an efficient, scalable manner. More specifically, the students will be introduced to Bootstrap, a popular CSS framework for developing responsive website and introduced to Vue, a progressive JavaScript framework for building rich user interfaces.

Experience: Project was really interesting and the topics taught weekly were really well prepared. With different lab exercises there to help us, it make things much easier to understand and apply it in our project
Improvement: nil

Experience: This module is the best if you are interested in frontend/web development as you will have the opportunity to create your own RESTful APIs and websites to your own imagination. Additionally, SMU finally took the opportunity to teach their students the current popular tech stack.
Improvement: For the assessments .. please increase the difficulty level. It's way too easy.

Experience: Great introduction to more in depth tools and technologies used to develop web application. However, the syllabus structure wasn't the best. For example the concepts of Vue was only taught at the later chapters and if one wants to incorporate Vue in their project they may need to completely overhaul how the project is done in order to fit Vue into it.
Improvement: Better structure for chapters

Experience: WAD2 is focuses on front-end development mainly on languages like HTML, CSS and Javascript.  You'll be learning how to use Bootstrap and Vue framework as well.   What's different from WAD 1 and 2 is that WAD2 will have a group project where you are tasked to create a functioning web application.   I would say WAD2 is more fun than WAD1 as firstly, it it more visual and you get build modern looking websites compared to WAD1 where websites look like they are from the 1980s. You can also showcase your project to your friends or future job applications as well.

Experience: Taken AY22/23 Term 1. Plus points: very simple and easy to understand concepts. Barely any workload and no finals. The recommend textbook is written by the Prof but you don't need to buy it. Prof is cool and plays electro music at the start and end of class. Minus points: Is basically an intro to some IT considerations in financial institutions across different business functions, neither here nor there. Definitely more catered to IS students. May be boring if you already have finance background.
Improvement: Just have to understand the slides
CourseDescription: Firms operating in the financial markets are among the most intensive and innovative users of information.  Over the years, voice-based trading has been replaced with electronic channels linking up market participants from across the globe. Traders are equipped with real-time price and market information, and are able to perform complex data analytics to advance their competitive edge. At securities exchanges, open-cry trading floors have been replaced by automated trade matching and straight-thru-processing (STP) has replaced error-prone paper-based settlements processing resulting in shorter settlement cycles.    This course provides an introduction to the financial markets products and services, markets and market participants.  Focus will be placed on the foreign exchange and equities products and the processes that support the trading and settlement of these instruments.  The course will include the architecture and design of the IT application systems that support these processes. It will cover how the deployment of STP has enabled efficiencies and eliminated risks by the end-to-end streamlining of operations within and across firms from trade initiation to settlement.  Objectives Upon completion of the course, students will have gained knowledge on: • The following aspects of the FX & EQ markets:    -  Markets & market participants    -  FX & EQ product    -  Trade lifecycle (value chains/ business processes) • The linkages between business value and the processes and systems. • Straight-thru-processing (STP) benefits & deployment for FX Spot post trade settlement processing through the design and development of a working system as part of the term project.

Experience: This module gives students a great basic understanding of financial markets - enough to create larger software/algorithms. The assignments (building/testing solutions on Excel) are interesting and relevant, but students with a background in entry-level finance will definitely be more comfortable with them.

Experience: The mod gives an overview (more like a crash course) of financial market theories over 14 weeks. You should have a good grasp of excel / have taken Spreadsheet Modelling before this mod, it will make life much easier. You have to incorporate financial theories and strategies into excel, for assignments like algorithmic trading or options pricing.

At securities exchanges, open-cry trading floors have been replaced by automated trade matching and straight-thru-processing (STP) has replaced error-prone paper-based settlements processing resulting in shorter settlement cycles.    This course provides an introduction to the financial markets products and services, markets and market participants.  Focus will be placed on the foreign exchange and equities products and the processes that support the trading and settlement of these instruments.  The course will include the architecture and design of the IT application systems that support these processes. Experience: If you have an interest for finance and are interested in how the trading softwares work, this is the mod for you. Non-IS students can also take it; just need to know excel. Most of the work is on excel (assignments and project). Paying attention in class is vital as the slides don't cover everything. Weekly revision of topics also helps you grasp future topics with ease. The demonstration using a trading simulation in class is quite useful to understand how trading works- you get to trade as well as design the excel sheet that automates the trading process. Overall, it is a very unique module and definitely suitable if you're interested in trading.  PS- don't worry too much about being a newbie in this field. The concepts are explained in a simplified manner and prof is really helpful as well.

Experience: Despite what other reviews say, this course is extremely heavy in terms of workload. Be prepared to spend upwards of 16 hours on your Take Home Assignments. There will be about 3 of them. This course does not require much critical thinking, as most of the time, you are repeating the steps that you've learned during class.  If you enjoy repetitive work, this course is for you. Also, prepare to spend the majority of your time debugging, and exploring new analysis tools. The content the prof teaches in class is not necessary to excel for the take home exercises.   This course does not have a final exam, which is why the projects are so intense. However, as of 27th Oct 2022, it seems that Prof Kam has implemented a mid-term for the coming semesters.   If you go under Prof Kam, do take note that he likes to paggro his students often. If you can take it, then this course is alright.  Lastly, if you like to live, don't take this course.
Improvement: Understand how to use QGIS (software) well, and you will be fine. Submit your assignments on time (they are workload intensive) and you will excel.
CourseDescription: Synopsis Effective planning and management of smart cities require urban planners to integrate and share data from multiple sources to the urban users so that they can be active participants in the smart city planning process.  GIS with its capability to capture, manage, display, and analyse information spatially is emerging as one of the important enabling tool in smart city planning. This course provides students with an introduction to practical applications of GIS in smart city management and planning.  Emphasis will be placed on (i) locating, acquiring and integrating multi-sources of data into GIS, (ii) understand the principles and methodologies of geocoding and geo referencing , (iii) become familiar with geovisualisation and GIS analysis techniques, and (iv) explore the technologies and possibilities of GIS-enabled Planning Support Systems for smart city management.  Pre-requisites There are no pre-requisites for the class and the class is open to all SMT students as well as non-SMT students.  However, a basic understanding of the principles of urban management and planning in the context of smart city is required.  Students who are new to the discipline of urban management /planning and smart cities are encouraged to do self-learning and research prior to the commencement of the course.     Objectives Upon completion of the course, students will be able to: •	Understand the basic concepts and theories of GIScience and trends of GIS technologies. •	Create, integrate, manage geospatial data and build enterprise level geospatial database management systems. •	Use appropriate GIS analysis functions to visualise and analyse business-related data. •	Model smart city processes using GIS’ advanced analytical methods. •	Design and implement cutting-edge GIS-based Planning Support Systems for smart city management.

Experience: SMT201 is an exciting module, especially for SMT students to learn more about urban planning and concepts around geography. Weekly Lessons are manageable and very useful. Hands-on exercises really allow us to understand the analysis and GIS mapping step-by-step clearly. Course resources and extra readings provided are also very insightful and comprehensive. Overall a very good experience!
Improvement: N/A

Experience: no exams. the reflection portion was abit kind of crap though, not sure how relevant it is.

This course provides students with an introduction to practical applications of GIS in smart city management and planning.  Emphasis will be placed on (i) locating, acquiring and integrating multi-sources of data into GIS, (ii) understand the principles and methodologies of geocoding and geo referencing , (iii) become familiar with geovisualisation and GIS analysis techniques, and (iv) explore the technologies and possibilities of GIS-enabled Planning Support Systems for smart city management.  Pre-requisites There are no pre-requisites for the class and the class is open to all SMT students as well as non-SMT students.  However, a basic understanding of the principles of urban management and planning in the context of smart city is required.  Students who are new to the discipline of urban management /planning and smart cities are encouraged to do self-learning and research prior to the commencement of the course.     Objectives Upon completion of the course, students will be able to: •	Understand the basic concepts and theories of GIScience and trends of GIS technologies. •	Create, integrate, manage geospatial data and build enterprise level geospatial database management systems. •	Use appropriate GIS analysis functions to visualise and analyse business-related data. •	Model smart city processes using GIS’ advanced analytical methods. •	Design and implement cutting-edge GIS-based Planning Support Systems for smart city management.

Experience: Ok, so I am writing this just a few days after my final presentation in this module just to give context. The profs Tan Kar Way and Hwee Pink are fairly reasonable and Prof Tan Kar Way has good teaching skills and is generally good when consulted. Additionally, given that this is a SMU-X module, it is expected that the sponsors will differ and hence the scope of research would vary from batch to batch.  Now onto my experience. The research on vaping among different audience caused significant advantages and disadvantages across all groups. While groups targeting universities and parents have fairly manageable reach to their audience, groups reaching polytechnic and ITE students had struggle to find a sample dataset as those in the earlier groups. Additionally, instructions should have been made such that surveys and interviews could be started earlier rather than after midterm presentation pitch, which by then is quite late. Some groups actually ignored the profs' instructions and went ahead with surveys and interviews which, again, gave them huge advantage to getting analysis before other groups that actually listened to the profs. Lastly, the sensitivity of the topic itself made it difficult for interviews to be held which caused even more delay in collecting data for analysis. The only few things that I felt were actually good were the compulsory prof check-ins via consultations. Even I disliked the fact that both classes were mornings so hopefully there is at least an afternoon class if you're hoping for one.  Overall, some things could have been managed better so that everyone is in the same playing field and that data collection for surveys and interviews could have been earlier. Would not recommend this module unless you have good experience with managing data collection and analysis skills through programming. Other modules such as IS434 would have covered mostly the same thing.
Improvement: Be prepared to do lots of survey data collection and manage interviews. Topics and sponsors will differ but be flexible and proactive with what needs to be done (even if the profs don't mention). Have a clear hypothesis and ensure that your survey and interview questions answer your hypothesis and theories clearly. Aside from that, good luck trying.
CourseDescription: This course provides students with a set of interweaving concepts from social science and information systems. Topics to be covered include big data, neural network, text analytics, social network analysis and applied analytics in smart city domains. Students will gain an experience on using these technologies to enable evidence-based decision-making across industries and be able to apply the concepts to interdisciplinary smart city domains such as health and enabled-ageing, home and environment, and provision of citizen-centric public services.

Experience: Learnt about text analytics and also using social science problem solving concepts (eg. blue ocean strategy & thinking hats) to work on the project. Its a SMUX module and depending on the sponsor, the workload will vary.
Improvement: NIL

Experience: The mod is a good balance between social sci and IS. You learn how to use skills in both departments to come up with your reports/group projects. You learn skills like how to do analysis on google trends, twitter, instagram and many more. In terms of bidding, don't bid so high since the majority of the students will be from SMT and it's compulsory for them to take the mod. The workload is quite intense, I find myself doing work every week. The practical lessons are not conducted very smoothly so be prepared for a lot of self learning too. But the mod is useful overall.
Improvement: The grading for the module is not very clear. In fact I find it quite biased (based on first impressions on a too short presentation time). Additionally, she has higher expectations in terms of what kind of analysis you do but she does not teach you how to do it. Again, a lot of self learning.
CourseDescription: Globally, there is an increasing trend towards the transitioning from ‘cities’ to ‘smart cities’. It is often envisioned that by leveraging ICT (information and communications technology), smart cities can enable its dwellers to improve their overall quality of lives across different domains – such as health, work and play. In this course, you will learn how to design, develop and manage these smart city systems. In addition, you will learn about the issues, considerations and principles, in the management of smart city solutions.

Experience: This mod builds upon your knowledge in IS/SMT111 (intro to programming (python)) AND IS112 (data management), so it was really an eye-opener in terms of how those mods can help you build something bigger. In my case, it was an app. If you want to know how to use APIs, create your own application (be it on the web or telebot), this is the mod for you. We were in groups of 6 (can form your team) so if your team can evenly split up the work it will be manageable. There were 2 paired assignments as well, can choose your pair. One of the most useful mods I've taken in SMU.
